pros: It is a great place to work.
cons: I do not have a con.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Gainesville, FL
pros: Professionalism and helpful. Care about your career.
cons: Grad students have to pay student fees

review_title: UF gives best diplomas in the state.
pros: The University paid for my tuition and a good salary on top of that for my graduate work.  Not too bad a deal to study in a fun, youthful city with many perks.  As a student I have access to cheap student tickets for great sporting and entertainment events, three excellent gyms to choose from, and there is a lively nightlife.  There are a lot of young people and the population is very diverse.  This is a great place to become networked to a wide variety of people and a good choice, especially if you are from Florida, to go to school because in-state tuition is so affordable.
cons: Its easy to get lost at a big university.  Although it has become a little more serious recently, Gainesville is still known for being a party town.  The city is small and can becomes boring after a while.  There's not much in the surrounding areas either - you need to drive nearly 2 hours to reach the beach.  Of course, like any bureaucracy there is a lot of redundancy, a lot of paperwork, and a lot of things that don't make sense.  But thats expected.  Another annoyance is that although tuition is included, fees aren't, so the scholarship can be deceiving.

pros: Very well organized school and good place to work
cons: I would like more money

pros: As an Resident Assistant, we get discounted pricing for housing, and a $350 fixed pay every 2 weeks. Being an RA is a hit or miss, depending on how lucky you are in getting a specific area/residence-hall, and who your Graduate Hall Director (direct supervisor) is. I was lucky to be placed in a great area (Tolbert) with great supervisors, the two years I worked there. Everyone was great and friendly, not a very challenging job, because I didn't have a lot of issues in my floor, but then again, you might not be as lucky as I was.
cons: Starting Fall 2018, the Housing Department increased the minimum requirement for activities that RAs have to meet significantly, so it was difficult to manage time between school, work and other involvements (I was in executive boards for two organizations on campus, and was focused on job-searching as well).

pros: Nice and good working environment
cons: There is nothing I could think of

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: - Flexibility to work on your time
cons: - Depends on your department

job_title: Doctoral Student in University Of, FL
pros: amazing inclusive perfect diverse helpful
cons: nothing nothing nada nada nada

pros: flexible work time and vocation
cons: not too much salary raise space

job_title: Research Associate in Lake Alfred, FL
pros: Good work environment with good benefits.
cons: Not that I think of.

pros: Great school, great education and great campus
cons: Not a lot of parking

pros: Good part time job opportunity
cons: Nothing to say about it

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Funding for PhD studies including tuition waiver
cons: Low wage compared to cost of living and contribution

pros: Very diverse and very friendly environment
cons: I have any cons to say

pros: Understanding, challenging, fun, new, exciting
cons: salary, benefits, competitive, bureaucratic, demanding

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Good students, always something to learn.
cons: Lot of work, little time-off

job_title: OPS Student Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros:
Great work/study flexibility
Good networking opportunities
cons:
Minimum wage 
Limit of hours you can work

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Good vibes and passionate colleagues
cons: Not much I can think of

review_title: UF is a good place to work if you're willing to put up with some challenges created by administration.
pros: Great benefits (health, etc) and flexible hours create an environment where you can take care of your family while building your professional career. UF is also large and very different across college and department, which leaves you with plenty of opportunities wether you're working for a high level administrative unit or department.
cons:
Lack of goals and organized planning around a common leading goal. This has been constant since I've worked here. Administration wrestles about with task forces, councils, and committees which do provide some constructive criticism in the form of rough plans or recommendations - however they often stay on the administrators desk due to all sorts of reasons from apathy, fear, or an unwillingness to see the work through via political change management. I know they get distracted with too much political noise around them, so it is to be expected working in such a large organization. 

To sum it up - I've yet to see leadership that makes sense to me in that they set a goal and charge others to lead and manage in the direction of that goal.

review_title: University of Florida Jacksonville Physician's, Inc.
job_title: Physician Coder I in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Can either work the traditional, flexible or alternative schedules (so long as you work within operational time and complete a standard 40 hrs a week). Decent benefits, friendly environment, and some opportunity to further education. The 403 retirement plan is not bad; for a very low price you can have it managed and aggressively invested. Also they have a concierge service on campus that is not advertised (car wash, laundry service), and the wellness center provides free classes and education. Very easy to earn CEU's, seminars and presentations offered throughout the years for free.
cons: Nepotism and lack of intra-departmental communication. Training for new people is lacking. Mail department nazi (seriously, why have someone put anything in a envelope if your just going to open it and put it in a box). Pay is low in comparison to the market. They preach about Accountability but try to be PC and too polite to hold anyone accountable for issues.

review_title: Department of Recreational Sports - Management Turmoil
pros: When I worked there they were flexible with the hours and let you have creative freedom. Big sense of community and togetherness with lots of different ways to hang out outside of work. If I messaged any of my old coworkers I know they would have my back and same for them if they messaged me. This is a good starting position even with the changes but be wary of what you want to accomplish in the role and ask a lot of questions about where you need it to land you.
cons: After they changed management and combined with Gatorwell, the new executive staff overmanaged workers and employees often felt that they were creating work only to please one person's creative vision. There's been lots of discussion about pay for hours worked and weird paycuts for different roles - Videographers made more than some designers and marketing staff made even less. Seemed to be based on skill of the position which is arbitrary because a lot of people worked above and beyond their pay grade.

pros: Learn a lot shift differential work 3 days a week
cons: Terrible coworkers and terrible manager in ECC department

pros: Great work environment, health-focused small city with many conveniences and within driving distance of the Orlando and Tampa Bay metro areas.  Very large research university with superior rankings, facilities and people.  Excellent environment for intellectual development and career growth.  A tremendous push to constantly keep improving makes UF extremely competitive.
cons: Being a very large corporation, UF tends to be quite bureaucratic and politicized.  Has been hit with State budget cuts for four years in a row, and faculty are expected to do more with less.  There is frustration when possibilities cannot be realized by lack of funding.  Opportunities for salary improvement are few and far apart.  Once locked in at your hire, don't expect your salary to increase substantially over the years.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Very little work requirements beyond working on my doctoral research- exception is having to work the department reception desk at least one semester. Its a good idea to seek out your own assistantship "projects" (eg. volunteering on projects, assisting to teach a class) so you can take advantage of the great network of academics and research that goes on here. Great all around infrastructure support. If you need an extra year of assistantship, they'll do everything possible to make it happen. Certainly makes you feel like they have your back.
cons: Lack of guidance. You're on your own. Which can be both good and bad. Need to be very self-motivated. Many masters and doctoral students were returning professionals, so it was expected that you had your own projects going on.

pros: Good benefits, working with bright and diverse people, much independence. Gainesville is a small town with some big-city amenities.
cons:
There is a pressure to work the equivalent of two jobs, with no other reward than getting to keep your job. This is reflected in the culture, where working every night and weekend (for free) is expected, and taking vacations is frowned upon. Most of its colleges are turning into research grant mills, with quotas one must meet; just like in sales positions, except with no incentive or bonus for good results. 

Faculty are forced to balance between guilt/neglect of teaching duties or poor performance evaluations, as bottom-line performance depends exclusively on research money. Tenure and promotion are based on deliberately unrealistic goals, to avoid awarding them and minimize costs.

pros: The job depends largely on the principal investigator (PI) you work for. Personally, I couldn't ask for a better PI. I have been placed in charge of many research projects and given complete freedom in terms of working hours. Combining external knowledge with current projects is encouraged, which motivates you to learn extra skills. I've taught myself how to 3D print, code in R/submit Bash scripts, and create 3D animations with Blender.
cons:
Cons occur if you there is a mismatch between your expectations and the PI's expectations. Be very clear with what you expect and ask what the PI expects when interviewing. In some positions, you may be stuck doing grunt work, such as keeping the lab organized, washing dishes, etc. Therefore, there will be little intellectual stimulation. 
Additionally, the job is not a great benefit for your career unless you want to bolster an application for graduate study.

pros: Assignments involving teaching or research are advantageous to career development but some are low level administrative work. My job was heavily teaching oriented and the department relied on me to perform unsupervised as a lecturer and to develop and expand course material. The full medical benefits are very good.
cons: The teaching assignment required more hours than I was paid for but time limitations prevented me from billing for that time.  This interfered in my studies and prolonged my program significantly.  Also, there are dramatic differences in the rate of pay for GTAs depending on the school and department.  This seems unfair and requires a great deal more work to survive in a liberal arts field than in engineering, for example, even though the work is the same. Notice about benefits is inconsistent from year to year and it is up to you to keep track of registration period and procedures or your benefits can be lost for the semester.

review_title: A great place to build a career if you have or can develop the ability to remain productive within a bureaucracy
job_title: Systems Administrative/Programmer II in Gainesville, FL
pros: When working in (campus) IT at UF, serious enterprise environments are at hand for gaining experience within. Fair pay / opportunities for advancement, and excellent benefits as it is a state institution. The town of Gainesville makes it easy to strike a work-life balance.
cons: Bureaucratic processes can be soul-crushing if you let them. Lots of unproductive meetings and departmental / unit-based silos, making it difficult/impossible for teams to collaborate across internal organizations. The other side of the enterprise benefit is that things move much, much more slowly. The software and tooling in production are 10-20 years out of date as compared with what might be implemented in a small startup or medium sized business, with (very) small pockets of exception where individual advocates make a serious effort to stay current.

pros:
O'Dome fam - make great friends
Mostly students
Learning environment
There are always new people so no one's stingy with teaching or helping

Ability to increase in rank (student supervisors and managers)

Flexible schedule, you pick the shifts you want and do (time, date, and type) - you must do a minimum of about 20 hours a month (unless it's not a busy season, then they don't seem to care)

You can choose between different shifts and avoid the ones you don't like, like Event Staff (customer service), Changeover (set, strike, trash, furniture, sweeping the arena for four hours straight, etc.), Tech. (requires you to take a class - lighting, audio, stage-building, etc.)

VIP seating for your family at your own commencement

5 cent raise at the end of the year
cons:
Hours go fast when posted online
Shifts are usually pretty short, so even if you do get a few they might not be enough
Some shifts will go short, others long.

Required to do commencement shifts, some holiday and break shifts

Multiple uniforms to keep track of depending on the shifts

pros: Top Public University with a corporate attitude. New President and existing VPs are  great.  Lots of professional development opportunities. Staff is treated well depending on department. If you work hard you will be rewarded.
cons:
Only departments with healthy budgets pay well.
If your lazy and have a "state worker mentality" than you will NOT be happy here(only a con for the  lazy - a PRO for working professionals that get it).
New President and culture is more corporate so if you are thinking that this is another state job where you can slide by with little to no work than again a CON but a PRO for enthusiastic hard working folks.
Faculty has a MAJOR chip on their shoulders. Frequent suits - HR must have hands full

pros: Cheap living nearby and free public transit for employees/students. Pay was acceptable. Really is a beautiful area to live.
cons: Horrible management, most principal investigators that I encountered are not engaged with their work and care little about their employees. There's a noticeable difference in the treatment of PhD students and full-time research assistants doing similar work. Almost all research assistant/coordinator positions are OPS meaning no benefits. University explanation for this is to keep short term employees from taking advantage of benefits, but they are just cheap. They offer tuition remission programs, but specifically in my case, we cannot take advantage of them given participant schedules. We are told to work around them which is impossible given our work schedule. At interview things like tuition remission, publishing opportunities, even plain job duties we're blatantly lied about.

review_title: Female academics are treated so poorly here.
pros: From my first day at UF, people told me that the best thing about UF was that no one cared what you did in the classroom or in your research, as long as you didn't rock the boat. This created a lot of freedom, but also a serious lack of standards for performance in certain divisions.
cons: Where to begin? Gender discrimination, workplace harassment, a for-profit corporate mentality that punished first-generation and low-income undergraduate students, deference to a tea-party legislature, right-wing political leanings that gave full freedom to aggressive pro-choice and pro-gun interest groups, a race to the bottom in graduate student and temporary faculty hiring salaries, a race to the bottom in family-friendly policies, isolationism, petty politics, and a climate of mediocre self-satisfaction that allows talented junior faculty to flee in droves while incompetent and abusive senior administrators shift ever more responsibilities down to the lowest-paid staff.

review_title: Excellent research facilities, student benefits, friendly colleagues and fun college town
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant (PhD) in Gainesville, FL
pros:
-Brand new, high-end facilities for researchers in Biomedical Engineering
-Good overall hiring package for PhD-level graduate students
-Lots of travel funding opportunities for conferences
-Cost of living is low in Gainesville. Although it is a small town, it has a lot of culture, music and things to do. If you are into the outdoors there are lots of springs, forests and oceans to explore. 
-Excellent work life balance, if you have time management skills
-Biomedical Department has social events that develop a community atmosphere within the department
cons:
-Funding can limit or decide the course of your research
-Limited exposure to opportunities for industrial networking
-Gainesville is small and isolated
-Faculty have low rates of tenure (<20% in my department)
-Stipends for PhD students are low ($20-$25K)

pros:
Great benefits, vacation and sick leave, good working hours, good supervisors, good atmosphere, 
lots of exposure to knowledge, fun reward parties and holiday parties, and good coworkers. Very good growth rates to advance in.
cons: The SOP's are hard to find in the work day to complete. The communication to employees and other departments are almost non-existent, they are very short handed with enough people to do the job, the equipment is old and dangerous, and some are broken, they like to hoard unusable items and equipment instead of disposing them, and even if a person works with a great record for a long time and makes a mistake they get treated like they are nothing and punished unfairly.

review_title: Sustained research opportunities, large school benefits in a small but vibrant community.
pros: As a very large institution and the flagship public university of the state of Florida, University of Florida offers a huge selection of research opportunities across many fields. Top notch programs allows for inter-disciplinary work and funding sources as well as professional networking. The university attracts international talent, and the university is committed to being a top institution in education and research.
cons: As a public university in a tourism-oriented state, University of Florida as been hit hard by the recession as state resources have plummeted with the reduction in travel. The university has fallen in various academic rankings recently. A hiring freeze has been in effect, though exceptions do crop up.

job_title: IT Desktop Support Technician in Gainesville, FL
pros: If you get a TEAMS position you are likely to be paid more and you will receive benefits. It is very easy to find housing near by and the buses are great transportation so you shouldn't even need a vehicle. If you do find yourself in a TEAMS position you should at least have the opportunity to move up or grow as a member of an IT department.
cons: OPS positions are typically abusive. Management has zero supervision because the chairman is not knowledgable enough to keep him in check which leads to laziness and faculty thinking that servers going down is an everyday thing. Boss earns the monster paycheck while I do all the real IT work which isn't even delegated to me. Servers were never backed up before I started working here. Some Novell servers were down for weeks at a time.

review_title: Seems like a standard University TA experience
pros: Healthcare for grad students is a big deal.  There are also a pretty good bit of things to do and a large number of grad students to hang out with.  The location is a typical big college town so if that's your thing the you'll be happy.
cons: They have ~50% of the classes taught by TAs.  You don't get paid more to take on way more responsibility.  Don't pay for parking it's a racket, just take the bus.  Also the student activity fees were not cool to tack onto grad students to pay for sports.  You have to use particular brands of soft drink at departmental meetings---not cool.

pros: UF runs Gainesville, FL. They offer better benefits than a lot of places. They have higher pay than a lot of places. Turnover is high, so they are constantly hiring.
cons:
TOP-HEAVY. Emphasis on managerial/supervisor positions is intense. Supervisor-to-worker ratio is very high. Employees (FT and temp) are treated as disposable. Upper-level management does not hide this; they openly encourage the mindset that all employees are replaceable. New ideas, outside thinking, efficiency are not important; egos and power-trips run the department. Supervisors are allowed to treat employees however they want.
Inept and unqualified workers are promoted to authority positions; employees work with a bare minimum of resources, and emphasis instead rests on their "customer service" with lab personnel.
No bonuses are offered to standard employees. Instead, sick days and vacation days are so high that they accumulate and employees end up with hundreds of hours they are never able to use.

pros: There is a fantastic benefits structure in place.  If you get a good supervisor who will allow you to utilize these resources there is a lot of flexiblity as long as you get your job done well.  It is one of the best places to work if you are a die-hard Gator fan.  There is a positive culture permeates the town and connects you with people you have never even met.
cons: Generally, a cultural division between faculty and administrative support staff.  The generational shift in incoming students may be one of the most challenging groups of folks academia has yet had to work with (this permeates the industry, not just UF).  There tends to be some entrenched feudalism and fiefdoms entrenched in the inter-departmental parts of the organization and between the colleges.

review_title: I teach a speaking class four times weekly to foreign students and professionals.
pros: You get to meet amazingly interesting people from all over the world, and learn about their cultures. You gain extremely practical and professional experience in teaching English as a second language. You make valuable connections at the Florida university that hosts your English Language Institute chapter.
cons: Aside from teaching four times weekly, you must plan for three hours, attend weekly meetings, and meet with your supervisor weekly; additionally, you are expected to go to activities during the week and on the weekends. I believe that these events are fairly compensated, but the Language Assistant position can end up taking more time than you initially wanted to invest.

review_title: Nice place to work and live
pros: Gainesville has a relatively low cost of living and most neighborhoods are generally safe. UF has an up-and-coming postdoctoral affairs office that provides career development workshops for postdocs and sponsors an annual research symposium. The staff in the Office of Postdoc Affairs is really great and accommodating. Beautiful campus where you can see alligators basking in the sun. Also a great athletic program. Overall, my experience has been positive.
cons: UF does not currently have mandated NIH salary guidelines, so postdoc salaries largely depend on the individual PI. However, the OPA did institute a minimum salary for postdocs in 2013, and they are currently trying to increase this minimum. The Career Resource Center provides some resources to postdocs but does not offer one-on-one assistance.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Lake Alfred, FL
pros: Beautiful, small scale research station. Lots of opportunity to work with local citrus growers to improve growing and management practices. Plenty of space for lab work and offices.
cons: Not much collaboration between research labs. At times it seemed like the faculty did not want to interact with each other. This made it hard to strike up collaborations and come up with novel solutions to citrus pest problems.  The center is a bit isolated from the resources of main campus.

job_title: Student Affairs Worker in Gainesville, FL
pros: I really liked working with certain co-workers at my office.
cons: There is a strong lack of background checks on employees at a higher level. There has been so many scandals that's happened in the past few years. There were abusive supervisors who often went unchecked. In order to cover up their mishaps, they would try to expel students and fire workers. There is a strong lack of respect of support for workers here and there is no amount of money that would bring me to work there again. People eat each other out and there's so much politics in the office. People at the higher up always try to down play terrible sketchy things that they do. This means throwing people below you under the bus.

review_title: Great place to work and earn your degree!
pros: Everybody loves the Gators! UF has diverse work environment and the cost of living is low compared to larger cities and towns. Fellowship and RA packages include tuition waivers and tuition is very low compared to other larger research universities. UF has some renown medical, engineering and science programs that comprise of extremely talented professors and professionals. The value proposition working and learning at UF is tremendous.
cons: The larger university makes it hard to distinguish oneself. Low tuition often leads to underfunded programs namely in many laboratories for some departments. The large department implies that changes are slow to occur. Gainesville is a college town.

review_title: Many years working for UF and still waiting for an opportunity for career advancement
pros:
benefits, vacation and sick leave accruals
State retirement benefits
UF is the only "real" employer in the city
cons:
Hire-and-fire HR policy. No real human resource management, no career planning. People are often hired into higher positions based on "who they know" or if they are a spouse of a faculty; rarely based on qualifications and credentials.
Male-oriented environment; very few management opportunities for minority women. Physicians and faculty have ultimate administrative decision-making although many of them have no managerial experience (financial or HR). 
Top leadership only cares about the faculty; staff is rarely mentioned or appreciated.
Very bureaucratic institution with many incompetent members.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Great colleagues that are friendly and easy to work with. Also Gainesville is a wonderful city to live in. Very affordable, laid back and comfortable. If UF is not your permanent destination, then UF is a great stepping stone to whatever next academic or industrial position you might be looking at. HUGE network and connections. People are very easy to talk with and build relationships.
cons: Not many, but I would say, only in very general terms, that the university tends to be a rather large entity that makes many policies, of which some tend to be not logical but inconvenient and not that flexible or open to feedback. But you can still easy have a wonderful life and work experience there since these defects tend to be just small spots on your windshield and not catastrophic cracks.

review_title: UF has a lot to offer, but satisfaction is heavily dependent on the unit where you work.
pros: UF is a land, sea, and air grant university in the wonderful town of Gainesville.  It is an AAU member with one of the largest student populations in the US and degrees in essentially every academic discipline.
cons: UF is a state agency so tuition rates and other key decisions are out of their control although efforts continue to liberate UF from some of these constraints.  Its size is also a liability and each college and the various departments supporting the university across campus work somewhat independently and things can take a long time to work their way through.

review_title: Great place for a PhD student
pros: The Physics Department has an outstanding group of researchers and also has collaborations with many other universities and investigation centers. Most of the students in the condense matter area finish grad school with 5+ scientific publications. On top of that you are in North Florida, you have the beach just one hour away, the weather is fantastic and the sports culture of the university is amazing. Also the city is very cheap.
cons: Gainsville is a small college town, which means that most people play a sport or go to the gym in the afternoons, party Friday nights and to the pool during the weekend. You do not have the range of activities of a big city. You may get bored.

pros: It was great to work here no matter what type of job you do. You can always get a great work/life balance for working in academia if you are not seeking for a competitive salary like working for industry. The work environment, like department infrastructures, labs, colleges, and students, are all great. Interpersonal relationships are easy to handle, people are always nice and willing to help. The benefit that university provides are well-round, health insurance and 401K are basic, dental/vision/law/pet are optional if you are at least a TEAMS employee. The management is not complicated, and you can always get a lot change to learn and strength your skills. Many repeated  routine work but always encouraging new ideas. Overall great.
cons: Below medium starting salary, hard to get promoted and salary raise.

job_title: Academic Assistant/Program Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: People are very respectful, professional and helpful.  Lots of training opportunities.  People move around departments once they have solid training, usually in search of better pay.  Good benefits.  Two weeks vacation plus UF is closed the last week in December and you get paid for those days too.  If you have a family, Gainesville is awesome.  Good schools, nice people, lots of nice residential areas.
cons: Some departments are better to work in then others (better pay, nicer people)- it's a smaller college town, so if you're used to a big city, it might get boring.

review_title: UF has not demonstrated any respect for their postdocs
pros: Good environment, morale, collaboration, research, and people. UF is attracting new talent in cancer research and is investing alot of money into research overall.
cons:
UF admin clearly cares more about the graduate students than the postdocs. This was demonstrated by a recent change to postdoc benefits (our official status and medical insurance was recently changed to become something below that of the graduate students). 

In spite of the recent large investment into research, the leadership seems to be going about this in all the wrong ways. The ship is only as good as its captain.

pros: Strong senior-level leadership (Mahla/Jimenez/Good), many very capable administrative-level leaders, and amazing students/residents/faculty. Great, quiet town to raise a family in.
cons:
Absolutely horrid pay--especially while working 60+ hours (no OT) because of under-staffing. Promised raises for exceptional performance, never received. Nepotism is the only way to advance. Most demeaning, demoralizing place I've ever worked with narrow-minded and self-absorbed mid-level leaders that steal credit and defer blame. Those with talent leave quickly, those with a sincere love for UF (or extreme compensation packages) stay to grit their teeth and bear it. 

Please note--experiences at UF are College and Department specific. I hear the College of Business and Engineering are quite nice and jovial.

review_title: The University of Florida is an awesome university for graduate students.
pros:
-They have a great selection of courses
-There are great professors
-They give awesome opportunities for research
-You are always pushed to succeed
-The weather is great
cons: -I didn't find too many cons about working at the University of Florida.  It was far from home for me, so that was a bit of a con.  Also, I am from the Midwest where the people are very friendly. In Florida, there is a bit of an East Coast atmosphere.  People are at a much faster pace and aren't as friendly as the Midwest.

pros:
Its academia, and can allow alot of freedom work wise.
The research can be interesting depending on the lab you are in.
Good benefits.
cons:
LOW PAY! This is a government job with the state of Florida. 
Also, Gainesville is  a "Company Town".  If you do science for living and are not a MD or a professor your salary is crap as there is no where else to do what you do for a living. The whole economy of the town is based around the university.
     I would only recommend coming here if you absolutely need a job, and then leave once a better opportunity comes along.
    Oh and other reviewers have mentioned that Gainesville is pretty boring place. This is absolutely true.

review_title: Management unfortunately has set the tone for the organization and the morale is low.
pros: Great facilities, staff and benefits are an advantage to this organization.
cons: Upper level management can be extremely difficult to work with and for.  Honesty is extremely important and the Executive Director regularly stretches the truth or tells half-truths to make himself look better or push his agenda further along even if his goals are not the same for the organization.  He will often undermine an employee or  project if you disagree with him.  Employees don't trust what management says and this makes it difficult to build a stable team pushing forward for common goals.  We have lost a lot of long-term employees because of this.

review_title: Nice people, low salary and job potential.
job_title: Senior Laboratory Technician in Gainesville, FL
pros: Straight 8-5 job, manageable workload.  If you are lazy and do the bare minimum, you'll be treated the same as people who work hard and care about their job....no incentive to improve.
cons: Slow to change or adapt, low salary compared to other government or university jobs, difficult to enter workforce, management not excited or amenable to new ideas or techniques and very reticent to give raises or promote hard working employees.

pros: University of Florida is a great company to work for if you are full time and salaried. I wasn't working on salary and for benefits so I didn't experience this. I did get paid a pretty good hourly salary though considering my position and experience.
cons: Very bureaucratic, lots of red tape. I was an OPS employee so I was paid hourly and didn't get benefits. I worked in video production and marketing, and most of the time I didn't get a lot of creative control over the project even if I was doing 99% of the work. The client was always right even if it degraded the final product. I had a lot of responsibility and a huge workload but no opportunity for job growth or advancement.

pros: Good weather (except for a couple of months in summer), located in a decent college town, great campus, plenty of parking spaces for graduate students (has separate spaces for  undergrads, grads, and staffs). They offer pretty good health insurance for GRA students and there is a huge infirmary on campus so i have never needed to look for clinics or hospital outside campus.  Also, they have  a lot of well-maintained graduate housing on and off campus with reasonable rents.  A couple of great gyms and several libraries for studying.
cons: All the workers are very laid back (or slow) so you need to be patient to handle any paper works through school. Campus is huuuugggge. Gotta walk quite long between places/buildings.

review_title: Below par but can be good for family
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Gainesville, FL
pros: You get 4 weeks of vacation in addition to 9 holidays, so you can miss almost 6 weeks of work.
cons: Bureaucratic, frustrating. It does not run efficiently, no one cares if you can really improve things because no one will get a bonus for it. Low technical competency. Lazy workforce (largely). You won't advance based on merit unless they're desperate. You can kiss up and live there to advance.

review_title: UF the good and the bad
job_title: Professor of Pediatrics in Jacksonville, FL
pros: As a physician job security is good. Once you are hired the organization supports you. The university has many processes that leads to  fairness in opportunity, advancement and salary. There is no discrimination by age, gender, religion or race and none would be tolerated.  Each individual has adequate opportunity for advancement although one must find time beyond clinical responsibilities. As a public institution the University and particularly the medical college is  doing good work. There is a dedication to caring for the disadvantaged as well as the insured. The  benefits are quite good although the State's economy is limiting some of the benefits at the moment.
cons: salary, state and institutional politics, support

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros:
- Teaching is easy
- Little meaningful oversight means you can sacrifice teaching quality for extra free time if you want to, which is useful during times you need to focus on other things
cons:
- Proctoring exams burns 3+ evening hours every couple of weeks
- Long hours grading exam free responses
- Lack of control over teaching content and methods means that if you actually care about your students you can't do anything about the low quality of teaching
- Feeling of irrelevancy to administration
- Most students truly don't care at all

job_title: OPS Laboratory Technician in Gainesville, FL
pros:
-benefits if you work more than 30 hours
-Opportunity to meet interesting people
-Professors are usually chill people
-Interesting research opportunities
-Many speeches and lectures to attend
cons:
-I learned quickly that mice research is not for me. There are many, many cages within the medical building. On the tour, they showed me where they euthanize and incinerate the unwanted research mice. It is all in a concrete basement. I love science, but I realized I wasn't open to vivisection and animal research being part of my job. This is a common aspect of research at UF.
-Professors can be casual about chemicals
-OPS workers are not always given healthcare
-UF is the largest employer, so it has a lot of control in the city.
-UF invests millions in fossil fuels

pros: The benefits are pretty good, being a state institution and all. General atmosphere is mixed. On one hand you have to deal with ungrateful students, and on the other hand you get to deal with inspired, ambitious students. Good Town to raise a family
cons: Recent budget cuts have made things rough. My unit lost 80% of our staff. The support staff that did make it is slow, unresponsive, and generally under educated.

review_title: Pros and Cons Like Any University
pros: Nice place to live, great place for families, excellent local school system if you have kids, many of the best undergraduate students in the state come here, excellent departmental structure to help junior faculty members succeed (at least in my department).
cons: Faculty union makes it difficult to reward outstanding performance, faculty union makes it hard to penalize non-performers, university is dependent on the state budget, very hot in the summer, undergraduate student population is a "mixed bag" in terms of academic effort and performance.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros:
A very nice city. When I got there in 2006, it was ranked as one of the best cities to live in. As a graduate student, the academics is one of the most important concerns, and according to statistics, this is getting much better thanks to good air conditioners:  Before 1980s, prominent scholars don't like to come to UF simply because it was too hot in the summer.

Now when you visit other state universities in Florida, e.g., FIU, you will see how much they want to be UF next.
cons: Job opportunity is not as good as big cities.  The Wal-Mart will post a slogan of "Welcome back Students" every beginning semester ----- this is a college town.

pros: Good university, good breadth of departments, ample opportunities to have diverse experiences, and a nice small town to work in. The atmosphere has been generally friendly and laid back. If you stay here long enough and work hard, the odds are good that you will have a chance to be promoted to leadership.
cons: As with any university, politics, restructuring, changes, some of which I did not agree with (if you've worked at any university, it's the same). I also dislike the me versus you attitude in the hospital. My biggest concern is some of the decreasing focus upon education quality in my department.

review_title: Historically good program but changes are needed...
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Very interesting cutting edge research happening in the chemical engineering department with lots of opportunities to interact and work with different departments. Conveniently located next a lot of other graduate students.
cons: The career options post graduation are very limited and Intel seems to be the only company willing to hire PhD in the past 5 years. Having a young faculty may be playing a factor into the lack of diversity where the students end up post graduation.

review_title: So far, I love working here.
pros: The work environment is wonderful. I work in an office that is very open and inviting. I deal with students on a daily basis and I have a great sense of purpose. It is a very relaxed atmosphere that is fun but very motivated to complete all tasks. I feel like I'm part of a team and that my thoughts, feelings, and opinions are valued. It's a great place to work.
cons: The commute is a bit of a challenge. Parking is quite limited and when it is raining, it is very difficult to get to work on time due to traffic and the on-foot commute from the parking lot.

review_title: Low pay, but not the worst
pros: If you're working here as an assistant, you're probably a student as well. The campus is nice and the staff are generally friendly. The pay is not bad and as a PhD student I got a full ride and stipend from a fellowship. Teaching was actually really fun, since I taught a core class and the kids seemed to care. Also healthcare.
cons: Pay is pretty low compared to what I could be doing in industry, so that's a big negative. Working in computer science, I feel like most of the work I do is pretty pointless since most things are pioneered by industry these days anyway.

review_title: Working at UF in the soil and water science  as a grad student
pros: Lots of career development opportunites. Great facilities. City is better than most other college towns. Plenty to do whether you like nature or night life. Low cost of living. Bus system is really good so there is no need to drive to work if you live close enough to campus
cons: Most things that come with college towns. A lot of younger people. Pay for phd students isn't all that high but the fees and cost of living also aren't as high as other places.

pros:
LOTS of opportunity for growth. 
Education benefits (6 credit hours per semester paid up front)
Great Benefits and health insurance
Lots of time off
UF closes for the week after Christmas and its paid for
Annual raises or bonuses depending on the state decision
Once you're in the system, you can apply for other jobs within the university after 6 months for growth opportunities.
cons:
Depending on the department, you can still run into crappy bosses. If this happens, get HR involved immediately and keep documentation. Still falls on the decision of whoever is next in the hierarchy and they do not always take concerns seriously. 
Ethics can be all talk, not enforced.
Not much flexibility in schedule.

review_title: Fun job with the right people
pros: the hours are very flexible. Sometimes you get invited to special events. It's fun to see what goes on behind the scenes of the theatre.
cons: The theatre is very far away from dorms/apartments. You usually have to work 3 hour shifts, at set time blocks, so if you have class starting at 3:00 and you have to work till 3:00 you can't come in 15 minutes early and leave 15 minutes early to make it to class on time....you have to pick a different shift.

pros: Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering classes can be challenging for all levels of various degrees. Professors are mostly very knowledgeable and helpful. Great university for research, plenty of grant money available.
cons: A few professors exist that are really really bad, whom you neither do not want to take any classes from nor you do not want to be anywhere near their offices. Since they are pretty infamous, you should ask around and find out before taking any classes.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in Saint Augustine, FL
pros: This job afforded me the ability to pad my CV, learn new techniques in electrophysiology, meet other scientists and learn about fields outside of my own.
cons: The institute where I worked was isolated from main campus. It was clear that certain faculty on main campus would deter students from joining labs at the institute. This led to poor feelings towards home departments, very difficult video-conferencing of courses and talks, and grumpy graduate students.

review_title: I have an excellent experience working for the University of Florida in Gainesville.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: The university has an excellent and dynamic scientific community. The atmosphere is collaborative as opposed to cut-throat competitive. There is a diversity of classes, departments, research resources accessible to students and employees.
cons: Not much on the negative side. The medical benefit package could be improved. I did not have dental or vision coverage and the general medical coverage was mainly limited to the "infirmary", only in extreme cases did we get referral to doctors in the hospital.

review_title: My time here has helped me develop as a leader and professional.
pros: The environment and people are highlights. There are many opportunities for one to grow as a leader and envelop the skills needed to communicate with the customers one is serving and with those that supervise you and the department. I have bonded with so many people and ceased lasting professional and personal relationships.
cons: At times there is a lack of organization. As an RA, decisions are not necessarily explained to you because it is above our pay grade, but we are expected to accept changes and decisions without any real explanation. A lot of trust is required to work with the department.

review_title: The Gator Nation is fun, but talk with Graduate Students before making your decision
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Many bars to go too.  Good sports culture.  Many departments to collaborate with.  Pay is good.
cons:
Not much else to do in Gainesville.  People are not very social or socially awkward, but that depends on the department you work for.

Top talent seems to be leaving.

As a research university, Florida is not very teaching oriented.  The classes are not very good because the teachers have other priorities.  The overall output is very high because the numbers of faculty are high.

review_title: Unless your a professor or upper management then it's not a place to stay long term.
pros: You can get a degree for free or a reduced rate.
cons:
1: The low salaries. Given that UF is the main employer in the area they can pay people what ever they want due to the lack of  local competition for an educated labor force. 
2: The university is in Gainesville, FL. a town located in the middle of nowhere in north central Florida. If it wasn't for UF this town would be another small farming community that no one ever heard of.

pros:
The manager (Gary Russell) is excellent at problem solving and interpersonal communication. For example, whenever I commit an error he initiates a one-on-one discussion to get to the root of the problem rather than just telling me I did something wrong and making me feel bad about it. He's a kind hearted man and empathetic boss. 

The office staff is also very diverse and friendly. As a Latina woman I feel very welcome here.
cons: Working in an office with no windows is not the best setting... however Gary does encourage us to take a 15-30 minute break to take a walk outside.

review_title: My time at the CHREC Lab
pros: I got to mess with a supercomputer and also got access to an Intel Xeon Phi. It was a great experience and it did help me learn a lot about their architecture and performance. I also got to work with the gem5 simulator and compare its performance with ODROID boards.
cons: After 4 months of learning and exploring between May - July 2016, I was told that CHREC was moving to University of Pittsburgh and the project I was working on, was moving to Pittsburgh as well. My research came to a standstill and was to be transferred to someone completely new at the University of Pittsburgh.

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The benefits offered as a state employee are excellent. They offer matching contributions to retirement accounts. Great place to start and develop job skills.
cons: Opportunities for advancement are limited. Merit increases are not regular and do not occur often. When leaving the university, they will only cash out vacation time and all sick time is lost, unless you are retiring. Pay structure is low for non-management and/or executive level employees.

review_title: Good Research Facility and nice town to stay
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: good research environment and a nice little town to stay. The professors are smart and have the experience to lead well. Generous in the pay towards students. The students are encouraged to do their independent research. They are allotted allowances for travel, conferences and other such. Seminars are quality ones invited from the best in the world. Diverse community is good.
cons: lack of communication between faculty and students. Some faculty members are not honest about their judgment of students. Large department sizes drain the value of community-effect within a department.

review_title: Received invaluable training and support from management
pros: The benefits are incredible. Management is amazing, staff is awesome and extremely supportive. Everything has been amazing so far! This job is a breath of fresh air! This university promotes long lasting employees, people who are looking for an organization to retire with!
cons: Hourly rather than salary, mediocre pay. Very hard to get a raise and pretty hard to move up the ladder. This job is a stepping stone for people looking to pursue higher education and interested in staying with the company a long time. Not really a con though.

pros: Great work environment, but it depends who the PI is. Diversity is a plus, opportunities for teaching for post-doctoral scientists. Flexible working hours.
cons: Whether or not you get benefits depends very much on the type of funding source you have. Too often do professors hire someone and claim they do not have funding for health benefits. It is too easy for them to wiggle out from underneath providing that basic necessity for their vulnerable employees such as OPT and post-docs.

review_title: Awesome Job If You Don't Mind Working the Graveyard on Weekends
pros:
Pick the hours you want
Can work up to 30 hours a week with a signed permit 
Can work on homework if it isn't too busy
cons:
Job is overnight (most times)
Can get boring sometimes so bring homework/study material
Can you only really access UF-related websites while at work; so keep this in mind when trying to finish homework assignments that requires off-site website addresses

review_title: Survey Research Center, not sure how to find it on here, so I picked the general UF company.
pros: Flexible hours, decent starting pay for a college kid, you can break whenever, online scheduling, really chill people and management, productivity incentive is nice too.
cons: Hard to do multiple shifts in a row, it starts to wear on you. Work slowed a few times and shifts weren't available sometimes. Rules can be kind of complex and ridiculous, but management will work with you for the most part.

review_title: Flexible but Unreliable Shifts at the O'Connel Center
pros: If you're a busy student just looking for an income, then this is a really good job for you.  They release a list of open shifts every month and you just sign up to work around your life/school schedule.
cons: Many of the shifts revolve around school.  So either you're working a shift for an event you really wanted to attend, or there will be a long time period of no available shifts because there's nothing going on at UF.

review_title: At least grad school is paid for
pros: Tuition waiver and modest stipend. Great weather and nature on campus. Reasonably smart student body. Great library. Teaching workload only 1 day per week, not bad. Rigorous program. Good professors and research.
cons: Bureaucracy is even more rigid than at most universities. Flexibility impossible. Very low pay, especially during summer semester, when pay is cut to half and teaching hours are also doubled or even tripled. Literally zero departmental support for external career opportunities like internships.

pros: The ranking of the university is good. You can learn a lot from your research. Good professor and classmates. Great research facilities.
cons: Being a Ph.D, you need to face a lot of pressure. A lot of deadlines and proposals. Need to publish high quality papers. But it deserves. With a Ph.D degree you would have better job opportunity.

review_title: UF: A Great Space To Run In Place
pros: The benefits are the ONLY reason to work here.
cons: This is a Land Grant University being run by a dentist.  The man has no idea what land grants are or why they exist.  He's been actively trying to turn the university from a great public institution into "the Harvard of the South."  The President's ego and ineptitude have been hurting the school for years, but even moreso in tight budgetary times.

pros: Great benefits and vacation, perks (like bus passes and cheap car rentals) of being a UF employee, tuition compensation
cons: Lots of red tape for everything, no flexibility, terrible parking situation, hourly employees were expected to work off the clock. They tout tuition reimbursement as one of their great benefits, but in my case the hours I was required to work meant there was no way I could take classes.

review_title: Great benefits, easy hours, impeccable tuition assistance program.
job_title: Administrative Services Coordinator I in Gainesville, FL
pros: The benefits are good, 22 days PTO/year + holidays + ~14 sick days. Unbeatable. Salary isn't bad for the cost of living. Hours are generally reasonable but obviously that can vary highly by department. Lots of good perks.
cons: Hard city for your spouse to find work if they don't get on with UF as well. Low pay compared to private sector. Lots of bureaucracy. Many people stuck in same jobs for a long time.

review_title: College of Journalism and Communication / Division of Multimedia Properties
pros: Great benefits and work with some very talented and professional people.
cons: Poor executive management.  No advancement opportunity.  Management is not truthful about budget or plans moving forward leading to a lack of focus and direction for the group and organization.  Though the majority of employees were polled at the beginning of the new Dean's term about what problems existed, nothing has been done to the current management.  Multiple people have been let go and were selected not based on individual need for the position or job performance, but because they weren't a part of the executive director's "favorites".  There are some great people that work here, but the environment is toxic.

job_title: Laboratory Research Technician in Lakeland, FL
pros: Everyone I've interacted with at CREC has been so kind, helpful, and incredibly knowledgeable in their respective disciplines. In practice, the bench work and projects are interdisciplinary which is a great way to apply one's knowledge to action. Everyone I work with understands the realities of being a student (like final exams, paper deadlines, and the time it take to prepare for such!) so they are accommodating to such obligations which is a refreshing change in my history of beginning work life in adulthood.
cons: It will take time to get accustomed and familiar with your lab's operations, project objectives, and protocols.

review_title: Resident Assistants have the best job on campus
pros: Being a Resident Assistant is a great way to gain leadership skills and make a lasting impact on students. Fellow RAs become like family as you work together to make your hall great. My favorite part was getting to know the students on my hall and planning programs for them on a regular basis. Cookie parties, movie nights, and study sessions don't feel like work, but you're getting paid to do it! Not to mention, you get paid to do a job from home, which is great most of the time.
cons: Being an RA can be challenging because you do not have a set number of hours you work per week, so sometimes duty calls at the least convenient times. For instance, if there is an emergency and you are in the hall, you have to respond even if you are busy studying or trying to relax. In other words, most work days end when you go home, but sometimes it feels exhausting when you get home and THAT is work. Another challenge is having to enforce housing policy with unruly and/or drunk students (which can happen often). Also, training happens every single semester you work, which is mostly boring and annoying because it cuts into your winter or summer break times.

job_title: Academic Assistant I in Gainesville, FL
pros: Good benefits- two weeks paid vacation plus a week at the end of year when the University is closed. Pension plan and benefits are good. Coworkers are amazing- nice, respectful environment. Pay for tuition if you want to take classes. There's a lottery for tuition scholarship for your children if they get admitted.
cons: There are times that are super busy and at other times there are big lulls. It can get monotonous. The department you work for could greatly influence how much you like your job and your coworkers attitudes. I got lucky but I've heard horror stories from other departments.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros:
The pros are highly dependent on which department and group you are working in. For me, the pros were a somewhat more flexible work schedule (no demands that I be in exactly at 9 am, though my advisor would call my cell if he had a question and couldn't find me in the lab).

Also working in a university environment is unparalleled in terms of exposure to arts, culture, music, etc.
cons:
Terrible pay and high student fees, but the cost of living in Gainesville is low. Benefits are decent, though no dental. 
Inconsistent work load and vacation time depending on advisor/department.

review_title: Excellent Place to learn and work
pros: I am currently finishing up my undergraduate degree at the university and I couldn't have been happier to attend UF. I started working in Shands in the Byrne Lab in the summer of 2015 and currently hold that position, which is very near and dear to me.
cons: Large school, very easy to get lost in the madness, especially if you're not a stem major, in which case its easy to feel like you're secondary

review_title: Stability and benefits, but be wary of "soft money"
pros:
- Stability (granted you aren't working on grant money / "soft money" - state funded positions are the way to go)
- Decent benefits (especially time off - vacation and sick/life event)
- Usually a good faith effort to raise salaries across the board, granted the state is in good financial health
cons:
- If you're in a position funded by grant/soft money, can be more stressful
- Decentralized nature of the University could be frustrating for some
- If the state money is rough, UF raises and/or job stability can suffer (although true firings/layoffs are rare)

pros: I got to work with a great team but there was too much politics. The culture was laid back but it was a fun place to work at.
cons: Salary was way too low and management only preferred their favorites. A lot of micro managing instead of focusing on work that needs to be done, there were issues about other things all the time. Growth seemed stunted, very slow in paperwork as well. Too much politics even within the team. Buttering up the managers was more fruitful than the actual knowledge of the subject.

pros: Their HR system is quite mature and seamless. Even a part-time employee grants access to the university libraries. The 403(b) companies they use were fine. I was able to get my retirement account transferred quickly once I moved on.
cons: Parking at the university is notoriously difficult. This is understood for students but part-time researchers will not fare any better. The standard advice is to buy a scooter and use that to get to campus. This works fine unless it rains - which in Gainesville in the summer happens daily at precisely 4 PM.

review_title: Excellent place to work but horrible pay.
pros: The benefits that come with working for the University are amazing as long as you are a TEAMS employee (full time/permanent).
cons: Not only do they start there employees at low pay but the only way to get a good raise is to apply for other jobs in the University. With that I know a lot of people that jumped around to a new job within the University every 6 months.

review_title: Couldn't ask for a better first job!!
pros: The staff is very friendly and understanding. It's a lot of fun working at TAPS! Get to interact with a lot of people that use the parking services. The pay is great for the job you perform, which is very simple.
cons: Few of the many visitors to the the parking services can be rude, so you got to deal with them.  The job once in a while can be really tiring.

review_title: Working for UF is one of the best choices I've ever made
pros: Learned a lot. Had a great mentor as an undergrad researcher. Was allowed to work on my own project. Had plenty of support. Compensation was average. The large package given to the university on the order of $120 million additional dollars is sure to increase the status of this university over the next decade.
cons: Many people burn out due to stress. 60 hours a week minimum are expected of grad researchers. So there is little work-life balance.

review_title: A great place to grow your career.
pros: Gainesville along with the Gator community is incredible, most people are super helpful and the area is a great small city to have some fun in or raise a family. It is a great place for early and mid career growth.
cons: With IT centralizing across campus and the health center it is actually harder to move up as there are fewer senior level positions available. Also, each of the IT groups seems to hire from within for senior positions so it is harder to grow once you get to a certain position or salary.

pros: Great faculty with lots of great research. With the grants and funding acquired by the professors they have bought some top notch lab equipment and machines.
cons: Some of the facilities are very old and need renovation. Researchers are undervalued by the university administration. There are also some teachers that don't get recognition for their hard work.

job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in Gainesville, FL
pros:
The salary that you receive as a research fellow is usually more than enough for living on your own, even if you reside close to the university campus.  Not having to pay graduate-level tuition and health insurance saves a great deal of money.  It's therefore possible to go from just having a B.Sc./B.A. to a Ph.D. without needing any student loans.

Some advisers may allow you to obtain multiple M.Sc./M.A. degrees, at no expense to you, other than time, on the way to a Ph.D.  This can be advantageous, as you can specialize in multiple disciplines and broaden your employment prospects.

Your research adviser will either make or break your experience.  There are some really great advisers who will push for you to work hard, help you along the way, and let you achieve a reasonably comfortable work-life balance.  They may let you work from home throughout the week, provided that you show up every so often and are productive.  Of course, there are other advisers who can make your life miserable.  This is regardless of if you have a research fellowship or just a research assistantship that is contingent upon the adviser's grant money.
cons:
There's very little flexibility for salary at the graduate-level, unless you're able to secure external fellowships or more than one internal fellowship.  Even with internal fellowships, the pay can vary from adviser to adviser.  Some advisers may pay only the minimum amount specified by the fellowships.  Others may augment the salary once their student has passed the written qualifying exam and dissertation proposal.

Most appointments at the graduate-level are half time.  It's incredibly difficult to jump from half-time appointments to full-time appointments, even for just a semester, no matter how many hours are worked.  As well, many departments now require students to function as teaching assistants before they can graduate with a Ph.D. Many of these departments refuse to let students receive simultaneous half-time appointments as both research and teaching assistants.  This is in spite of the fact that students may be engaging in both research and teaching in a single semester.

review_title: Local Public Broadcasting Affiliates Provide Stimulating Yet Comfortable Workplace Environment
job_title: Director of Corporate Support in Gainesville, FL
pros: People tend to work here a long time.  We have an incredibly high percentage of staffers with more than 20 years at the stations.  Management is committed to the long-term stability and satisfaction of the staff.  State of Florida benefits are available to us, and our physical workplace is outstanding.  Infrastucture support (IT, office supplies, business office, etc.) are all responsive and helpful.  We work in the middle of a large university campus, which means we're surrounded by youthful activity.
cons: As with many positions, the positives are also some of the negatives.  This is a state job, and much of the staff treats it as such.  What we do - providing public radio and television for the region - is a noble endeavor and one I'm proud to be a part of, but a majority of our staff works for a paycheck, not for our listeners and viewers.   This tends to make positive change difficult to engender, which is frustrating.  Because people tend to stay here for such a long time, there's little upward mobility possible, and when there ARE retirements, positions are likely to be restructured - so it's hard to set one's sights on a particular position and grow towards it.  We work in the middle of a large university campus, so parking is a constant struggle.  My position requires me to leave the office (and campus) several times a day, and it's hard to look, think and act like an executive after the third half-mile walk to the car in the Florida heat.

pros: Good population, its fun to work with students. Lots of resources for fitness. Everyone is dedicated to what they are doing.
cons: The gym setting creates a certain atmosphere. Not all staff have the same level of skill so the experience can vary depending on how helpful each individual is.

review_title: Very Good School for Graduate Students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Take very good care of their graduate students, salary continues to increase over years to reflect changing economic environment, getting paid is never a problem, lots of resources at your disposal to prepare yourself for the next level
cons:
Graduate school can be a time sink and often times people get stuck here and never leave.  Have goals and dates and stick to them.  Must be highly self motivated.

Also student fees are annoying because they take money out of your paycheck and give it back to the university.  ~1500 dollars a year

pros: Fairly good salary, good access to sports facilities, awesome city. The music scene and restaurant scene in Gville is pretty good as well - the Top is the best!
cons: Bureaucracy gets really irritating to deal with. Only two gyms on campus which are usually quite crowded - SW is difficult to get to unless you live near it.

review_title: Great place to be a student and researcher, but poor compensation and backwards rules overall for the amount of work.
pros: Great diversity of research opportunities and experience. In my CLAS department anyway, there is a very flexible structure regarding how you meet your work hour requirements. With about 50% of classes at UF taught by GAs and TAs, they'd better be flexible! They also started recently offering free health care for all grad students (though I've had some major issues with their coverage).
cons: The compensation for the amount of work is not very good. It's great as far as graduate assistantships go, but UF definitely requires more work from graduate students than a lot of programs I've heard about. Further, while they offer free health care for grad students, which is great, they don't have vision or dental plans (though they started discounts this year). Further, the cost to include my spouse or child is ridiculously expensive compared to independent coverage I researched myself. The other problem with the GA/TA type positions is that UF requires you to be taking a full course load as well (9 hours), and they make us pay fees. Therefore, an entire paycheck of the already low pay goes towards fees. If you're not yet a FL resident, it's more like 2 or 3 paychecks. I've had to hunt for independent studies while I've been working on quals since I'm pretty much done with classes. The other problem lately has been their cutting of classes due to budget problems so it's even harder to find courses to fill the requirement to keep getting a paycheck. The administration also doesn't really seem to appreciate it's graduate student population-it usually feels like they're just trying to keep us in check.

review_title: Graduate Hall Director in UF Department of Housing
job_title: Graduate Hall Director in University Of, FL
pros: Great experience if you want to be a supervisor. Awesome benefits like free housing, high pay and flex-bucks. I really enjoy working with RA's. It doesn't even feel like a job, more like an extracurricular activity. Very inclusive culture. I highly recommend the position.
cons: The downside is that you have very little job security. It's very easy to get caught breaking any rule since you live and work in the same place. And if your fired, you loose your housing.

review_title: Perspective of working at the University of Florida
pros: Being a land grant university it has provided ample opportunity for research. This allows people to grab fundings and enjoy huge networkings with people related to their research. Very good leadership but this can be based on the departments and colleges also. Overall a great place to work.
cons: No any bitter experience that I know of. Anything that has occurred to other people might be an personnel issue. Great Gator Spirit.

pros: At UF there are many perks including having great colleagues, good resources, good weather, great sports, college-town life, reasonable cost of living, and a high quality of students and faculty. Also having alligators on campus is cool. There are many cultural events to attend, particularly for a city as small as Gainesville.
cons: Public universities rely a lot of public funding, which puts pressure on for having grant funding. Also, the traffic in Gainesville is really bad - not LA or NYC or Seattle bad but worse than traffic in much larger cities.

review_title: Management Analysis Coordinator responsible for delivery of monthly billing services and reporting
job_title: Management Analysis Coordinator in Gainesville, FL
pros: Supervisor encouraged initiative and provided support as needed. Helpful co-workers. Department recently underwent a lot of changes, both in management and strategy that allowed changes to obsolete practices and pre-set methods. This is also providing some opportunities for growth. Some of the benefits like number of paid time off days and maternity leave is very good.
cons: Telecommuting is not encouraged. Salary ranges are low. No clear growth path if you want to stick to one field. Not much available in terms of formal recurring training.

review_title: Great place to live and work
pros:
Living in Gainesville is amazing--always something going on and it's truly a beautiful city.

Working at UF definitely has its perks--specifically, if your spouse or partner also works there (and you don't have kids) the health benefits cost something around $15-30 a month (for both of you). Very good benefits offered.
cons: Like most administrative roles, the opportunities for advancement are limited and you have A LOT of red tape to deal with across the university. But that isn't anything different from working at other universities and isn't unique to UF.

review_title: A good place to work, but choose your department and position wisely in trying economic times.
pros: Excellent work-life balance; good people culture; depending on department, good training and professional growth opportunities; opportunities to sit in on various lectures and seminars abound.
cons: Training, growth opportunities and day-to-day experiences can vary wildly by department; due to funding challenges, some departments have occasional hiring and promotion freezes while others even experience cutbacks; pay can be poor in relation to the education and experience required to be competitive in the "university town" setting.

review_title: Flexible with it's students and their schedule but loses professionalism in the process
pros: It pays well for a state job, good job security, flexible, and benefits such as 6 hours of classes free
cons: Each department is different at UF, but it is all political. And you are made to feel that not all you should only make certain networking connections to rise in the ranks. Employees are so secure in their jobs that there is a lackluster haze surrounding productivity. If it doesn't get done today then tomorrow or the next day is a common attitude.

pros: Great working environment, and a big school with many departments. The research is pretty excellent, and the fact that the school is affiliated with the UF Health Hospital, makes for great opportunities of top notch research. If you are leaning towards academia, this is the place for you.
cons: Small city, with not a whole lot to do that does not involve the hospital or University. If you are leaning towards biomedical/biochemical industry, the opportunities around here are not the best. A few start-up companies around, but the pay is not so great.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Somewhat livable wage while pursuing advanced degrees,  flexible hours, gator grad care (with a dental cleaning), nice coworkers/professors, learning focused
cons: TA-ing gets in the way of research (and classes), unpaid overtime (often assigned more work than can be done in the allotted time), have to pay fees to work (~$2k/year), end up revisiting elementary material too many times, only mild control over which courses you TA causing a learning curve each new course.

pros: Very flexible hours and easy to get shift coverage for exams or for club/group events. Very little management from superiors allowing you to assist students the way you want to. Mainly student run, so that means a very relaxed environment.
cons: Pay is awful, we get payed much lower than the average undergrad TA. Very difficult to get any upward mobility. You will have a new boss quite frequently and will have little to no training.

job_title: Competitive Sports Supervisor in Gainesville, FL
pros: The people who work at Recsports, both peers and superiors, are a joy to be around. I enjoy going to work every day and have formed sincere relationships outside of the job.
cons: Since there are so many students hired, hours a scarce. While it is possible to pick up extra shifts from people that drop them, do not expect too many base hours a week.

review_title: Be certain you want to be here
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Laid back atmosphere with an emphasis on patient customer service. The management seems to be relaxed and enjoy their work at the institution.
cons: The work environment is not optimal for those looking to advance within their career. There seems to be some difficult decision making made by the management here. It seems like more of a good ol' boys club running a health institution.

review_title: Good place to work in IT
pros: In central IT employees are given freedom to choose and complete their work. Morale is high and the office culture is great. Management doesn't micromanage and appreciate and reward hard work. Promotions of title and salary are given when appropriate. Able to attend training and conferences on leading technologies.
cons: Understaffed in my group. As a result consistently the only person working on a specific task.  Management recognizes it but filling positions has been slow.

job_title: Assistant Director of Clinical Research in Gainesville, FL
pros: Multiple resources to optimize the conduct of clinical research and maintain compliance with institutional, state and federal research requirements.
cons: Although UF strives for excellence in research, departments limit research workforce capacity through a lack of understanding of the research process and staffing needs.

review_title: Sprawling inefficient bureaucracy, but some nice people
pros:
Location/weather
Collegiate atmosphere
Fair compensation
Good benefits
Some great people
Decent work/life balance
cons:
Inefficient bureaucracy at times
Disorganized and inconsistent management
Some difficult people
Expensive and inconvenient parking
Lack of institutional accountability
Politicized work environment

review_title: Great Place for students needing flexible hours
pros: Excellent, friendly environment, Hours are really flexible. If you are looking for a job as a student then this place is perfect for you.
cons: The pay isn't too good too begin with, although you can get .50 every other semester if you perform well. Hours were also only from 9-5 Monday through Friday so no weekend work.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
