pros: The working environment is great. The supervisor isn't too pushy, and for the particular TA job that I have been doing, as long as I strictly follow the rules, attend the meetings and do as I am told, and maybe put effort into teaching, I will be in good shape.
cons: Sometimes the paperwork is too long a process for international students. My first pay came about 2 months late.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Gainesville, FL
pros: Good hours, casual work environment, they work around a student schedule, you know what is expected of you, good office morale and friendly staff
cons: Pay could have been better, my office was open when the rest of the university was closed and it felt like a waste of time, I often couldn't take off if I was sick if nobody could cover for me

review_title: Basically just a college town with nothing else
pros: Warm climate, friendly people. Many brilliant professors to work with. In a small town could be a good thing if you need to spend most of your time in your study and work.
cons: Location is the biggest disadvantage. Florida is far away from large job markets, and the university is in a small town.

job_title: Project Manager, IT in Gainesville, FL
pros: Get to work with great minds who are intent on improving the academic and practical landscape for our nation's students. Pay is decent for Gainesville and benefits are great. Get almost four weeks off per year not to mention way more paid holidays than you would in the private sector. Who else gets homecoming off? Superiors provide excellent feedback and mentorship.
cons: Pay is not as high as the private sector, but that is offset by the work environment and culture.

review_title: Good pay for a decent job
job_title: Field Technician in Vero Beach, FL
pros: The pay is better than most jobs I’ve had, and the experience makes it worth it. Professors treat you very well and coworkers are great.
cons: Job often asks you to work over 40 hours with no overtime pay. Communication with the professor I worked with and other lab mates when I was not in the lab was poor. Some parts of the job really needed two people, but I was able to manage.

review_title: Fixed salary for 4 years, no promotion. Salary is even decreased by increasing internal fees.
pros: Good location. In some specialties, s.a. Medicine or Business, PhD is quite valuable. Also, in Biology or Chemistry PhDs tend to earn more. Also, you have access to all journals, publications, videos, databases, etc. So plenty of opportunities to do research.
cons: Juicer. The purpose of the University is to extract from you cash flows, and give you back an education which nobody in the country really respects. Unless you study by yourself in addition.

review_title: Worked as a student employee part time
pros: Very flexible and understanding when it comes to student employees. Being a university, they understand that education comes first and if there were ever any conflicts with anything education related and the job, there was never a question of which came first.
cons: They limit student employee's hours to 20 a week unless a waiver is filled out by an adviser clearing you to work for 32 hours a week. Very minor, only a con if you're looking to work more than 20

review_title: Competitive assitanceships if you can get one
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Flexible hours, 20-25 a week with a minimum of 9 credit hours in classes. Take 6 hours of course work and 3 in research credit. Contribute to the Graduate Assistants Union, they got research assistants and teaching assistants health insurance.  I was always treated like a professional but RA experience is probably very dependent on your adviser and department.
cons: You still have to pay student fees, as much as $600-$800 a semester. Regular employees of the University do not pay fees.

review_title: Pretty much what you'd expect from a college job. Great people, low pay, overall nice experience for a first time job.
job_title: HRE Marketing Designer in Gainesville, FL
pros:
Great people who want to see you succeed. 
Very understanding when it comes to you taking the day off or personal issues. 
Not too many "office politics".
Great first time job for a student.
cons:
Low pay.
The work can be really boring and it takes way too long to complete a project because everything gets put on indefinite hold since there are so many people who need to approve it.

pros:
*The staff will work to accommodate your needs
*Student health care
*Plenty of on campus parking, activities, and groups
*Living in Gainesville is great!
cons:
*While supported, you still have to pay some class fees
*Space can be limited for research locations, so labs can be required to shift locations
*On campus food selection is somewhat limited

review_title: Graduate program in food science and human nutrition
pros: The food chemistry division of the food science program is pretty good and strong. We have at least 3 labs doing food chemistry using LC-MS, GC-MS. very friendly environment in the department. often have social activity within department.
cons: Lack of dairy and cereal program. The building is kind of old.  Usually don't offer assistantship to master student. Part of the food science program is located off the main campus.

pros:
-Large networks
-Decent professors
-Lots of employee perks (healthcare, gym, legal services, counseling, etc)
cons:
-Undergrad quality is moderate
-Large bureaucracy

pros: I started out as a mentee of a faculty member and then became a paid research assistant.  Structure of the college is good and obviously very supportive of research.  Colleagues were great.
cons: Only con is that it is a little bureaucratic at times and there was some difficulty getting things done quickly in regards to clearance and access to certain things.

job_title: Aircraft Maintenance Officer in University Of, FL
pros: UF is full of intelligent and fun people, and the work is generally meaningful and rewarding.
cons: At UF, everything depends on which professor you are working for.  Some are honest, and some are not.  Some are concerned for the well being of their staff, some are not.  Unethical behaviore from professors is generally tolerated or ignored by the administration.

review_title: Flexible work conditions but hardly a career path
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Working for a university is very flexible. I work whenever, wherever - so long as I get the work done.
cons: University rules with respect to employment are very strict - it's difficult to get a salaried position during research. Hourly pay without benefits is pretty standard. Basically you are working for the state and have to deal with the bureaucracy thereof.

job_title: Student Advisor in University Of, FL
pros: benefits, free tuition, professional development options, transferrability within 6 months, opportunities to advance, adult child able to attend for free
cons: administrative red tape in academic unit.   Faculty put in student affairs roles, and not fulfilling the job duties.   Faculty political games.   Institution still has some old boy attitudes.   I was happier in student affairs, but the Dean of Students creates issues.

pros:
- good benefits
- short commute
- affordable cost of living
cons:
- highly micromanaged
- limited growth potential for admin staff
- way too much emphasis on politics, not enough on programs
- too many egos in a small town

review_title: My experience ranged from answering phones to scheduling language courses for each semester.
pros: Sick days off and Christmas vacation off.
cons: Downsizing the departments and putting more work on the Secretaries.

review_title: Worked as a teaching assistant part time
pros: Very understanding when it comes to graduate students. They know education comes first if there were any conflicts with anything else. They will give you a training and let you utilize what you learnt to help others.
cons: As a graduate student, we can only work 20 hours a week and there are other limits for international student. It's almost impossible for a student to work over 20 hours without some special "waiver" which is hard to get.

job_title: English Teacher in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Hardworking,dedicated and persistent.Iam able to set goals and accomplish them under the targeted time frame.Iam a good team player.
cons: I tend to expect too much from my students,so much that I'd they don't achieve I blame myself.I have always wanted perfect students who make very few mistakes.

pros: Excellent responsibility and very reasonable compensation.  Great team with which to to work
cons: Short staffed for responsibility given.  Poor management skills from supervisor.  the system permits long-time manager to throw new managers under the bus.  too much micro-management.  Political salvation was more important than truth.  Sometimes we are all permitted to be just a little too human.

pros: Great campus with tons of opportunities for jobs in almost any field. Most OPS jobs pay pretty standard $10-14, but the work load can vary greatly from some lab tech positions to general maintenance positions. Campus is very clean and many positions run throughout the year, independent of the undergraduate semesters.
cons: Can feature a lot of bureaucratic nonsense, like any large institution. There are tons of lazy administrative employees that will waste your time over actually helping you resolve problems/ dilemmas.

review_title: Excellent! Great place to start a career!
pros: Depends on the college and department you're in. Most are excellent with nice, helpful people. Even if you dont like the job, hold on to it and use it for experience. Then move up the ladder! Once you get you're foot in the door at UF the opportunities are limitless. Not to mention you can use it to go other universities.
cons: not the best pay, but great benefits! State employee!

job_title: Community Assistant, Graduate and Family Housing in Gainesville, FL
pros:
- Friendly people
- Encourage learning and growth
- Help you connect to other areas of the university that are helpful in your work
- Great multi-cultural environment, with the opportunity to get to know people from all over the world with a multitude of different academic and career interests
- Good training and orientation
- Ability to propose ideas and implement them
cons:
- Small budgets for some jobs
- High turnover due to different schedules of student graduation, one spouse working while the other studies, etc.

review_title: A constantly changing and interesting environment.
pros: The hours are extremely flexible and you can tailor them to your schedule.  You can work 5 days a week, or once a month.  It also teaches you some useful customer service skills and technical skills.
cons: It's pretty difficult to get to know anyone well if you don't work there constantly.  The work is tiring for minimum wage.

pros: Great place to work if you get into the right department. Fantastic benefits, time off and retirement plans. They will also pay up to 8 credit hours towards a bachelor's degree. There are also lots of opportunities for education I internally.
cons: Pay increases are limited to 10% when moving within a department, no matter how big of a jump in responsibilities you are making. This causes a lot of movement throughout the university in efforts to get a pay raise.

pros: Pretty campus. Always the opportunity for exposure to  new ideas. Comes with some healthcare benefits, membership to gyms, and you can ride the bus for free
cons: Healthcare plan is shoddy. Coverage is not great and dental is laughable. HR is never straightforward with you.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist II in Gainesville, FL
pros:
Benefits including a lot of paid time off, ability to change positions within UF, training opportunities to gain new skills sets, beautiful campus

My reason for job searching is relocation; I'm searching UF opportunities across the state first :-)
cons: Parking is the only "con" I can come up with, but any large organization would present same challenge

pros:
- Great pay & benefits
- Low stress
- Great work environment
cons:
- Unless the position is that of a faculty, staff's opinion is not often used even though administratively we do most of the work. 
- Always watch out for the balance between helping a faculty achieve results and the legal liability, often times the faculty is not preoccupied with the legal ramification of their actions.

pros: The Conference Department management really cares about the department's employees. If you're a good worker - punctual, attentive, organized - they will take care of you. I've never seen a place that is so easy going with time-off requests.
cons: No opportunity for advancement. It's a small department and the boss is very competent, and he's not going anywhere. However, there is opportunity to transfer within the University.

pros: I have been working at UF for 7 years at the department, main administration, and center level. I really like the benefits that the university offers to its employees. They offer a great variety of health insurace and leave.
cons: Raises are very strange. Last raise that UF got was almost 2 years ago. No performance raise.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Orlando, FL
pros: It's a Great school to postdoc for, and has many connections to state and federal agencies and NGOs, which will hopefully aide in landing a full time job afterward.
cons: UF postdoc not living in Gainesville, thus I don't get many of the benefits associated with being a UF student or employee (such as free/cheap healthcare at the on campus clinic).

review_title: Great place to do research, study, and enjoy.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Gainesville, FL
pros: Cheap living cost. 2 bd APT ~$800. Lots of parks around. 2 hr driving to Orlando, Daytona, or St. Augustine. Lots of cheap cruise to Caribbean. Sunny and nice weather.
cons: Not so rural, but still relatively boring city. Public transportation kinda bad.

pros: Excellent group with extensive knowledge who offer amazing support
cons: The curriculum is not structured and the student is expected to understand and work it out by himself. Some the STEM in college of pharmacy courses are also not valid for OPT extension due an error in the code as result of which we do not get additional OPT extension and only get 12 months of OPT

pros: The institution is so large that it provides opportunities to gain a variety of experiences in a fast pace environment. In this environment, you can gain a strong knowledge about managing people, your ethics, and managing relationships.
cons: The University is so large that you can be overwhelmed with the work load, the fast pace, and the responsibility that you must take to build connections.

review_title: A vast campus with very good research as well as recreational facility
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: As an international graduate student, I liked the multidisciplinary research opportunity as well as working with people with diverse cultural background and nationality. I also liked the beautiful campus a lot.
cons: Stipend for graduate students is not very high, as is the case at any other university

job_title: Student Software Engineer in Gainesville, FL
pros:
-Really flexible with student class schedules.
-Great opportunity to meet people.
-Really forgiving of mistakes and open to letting you learn things.
cons:
-Low pay for this type of work.
-None of your coworkers are around for a year or more so they're students too. Your development team will have people move in and out every semester.

pros: University benefits are good, particularly time off policy. Compensation is fair. I think UF as a whole is a good organization, just not in Jax.
cons: At least in pediatrics, a lot of disrespect coming from management. Everyone hated working with bipolar Christine, including other departments. Senior leadership has issues too. The assistant director regularly sleeps on the job, but the rest of us get lectured about the quality of our work? PLEASE. That is why turnover rate is so high.

pros: Nice place to work, nice weather, and if you have a good professor to work with then it is good
cons: Overall it all depends on what work you do and who your supervisor is. If he/she is good then your experience usually will be satisfying. University does not pay so well as the other employers

review_title: Mixed experience as a Graduate Research Assistant
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: As a graduate research assistant in the School of Medicine, my salary was fairly competitive and included tuition in a competitive PhD program.
cons: There was a focus on future postdoctoral employment and there was not enough emphasis placed on optional careers in industry.

pros: The scedule can be very flexible and it is close to classes.
cons: The pay here is the worst. They do not treat their student employess with any respect. When they are the ones that run alot of the jobs on campus.

review_title: Pick an adviser you get along with
pros:
Work with cutting edge research
Relatively good benefits including health care
Good direction and information about what is expected of you
cons:
For most graduate researchers the pay is very poor. 
Depending on the adviser hours can be very long with minimal vacations
Too much focus on publishing

pros: UFL is a nice place to pursue your PhD, provided you work with right adviser.  The young professors work with cutting edge technology.
cons:
The salary is not up to the expectation, specifically in Computer Science department. Also, 
working with the older professors can be regretting as they are slow and overpowering.

review_title: Professional Growth directly depends on your Career choice.
pros:
State Ret. Acct
Paid Holidays
Paid Vacation
Paid sick time
Employee Education Program 
a professional but relaxed atmosphere
cons:
Progress is slow
Salary increases nearly non-existent in recent years
Shifting to a "Self insured - Medical insurance program"
Must be willing/or able to change jobs every 8-12 months within the university system in order increase salary, limited on certain positions

pros: The University of Florida has a laid back environment, especially in the College of Agricultural and Life Sciences, friendly workplace. The pay is competitive.
cons: The parking unavailable or so far away that you have to take a shuttle- this is not worth it. There is  not enough workspace and/or officespace. The space they gave me was extremely crowded.

pros: Great, motivated, friendly co-workers. Getting to work for the school was an incredible experience. I loved helping out the Gator community.
cons: Sometimes had to do field events to help promote fundraising to students. Many students weren't interested. Often, work would be given by multiple superiors without communicating.

review_title: Great benefits, not so great pay.
pros: The benefits are great and there are all the perks of being in a University setting.
cons: As in all of academia, the power and influence are with the administration and faculty -- staff have much less clout regardless of educational attainment.  Also, salaries for faculty, graduate assistants and staff tend to be below the national average.

pros: The schedule is flexible for students and the atmosphere promotes growth and leadership experience while also providing mentorship from full time employee
cons: There aren't many downsides to working at the University of Florida. They understand that school comes first and are flexible with scheduling.

pros: The benefits, advancement opportunities, the people that you make contact with becoming friends.  Most of all the student work forces are fantastic and fun to work with.
cons: State job wages are strapped. Wages are based on what the Board of Trustees issue then it is left to the Directors to split and it is not always fair to non-administrators.

pros: Working environment is not bad. Professors here are good enough. The HR and secretaries are  nice and kind
cons: Chances are that you meet very low supervisor and they just push you to work and threat you on not continue your contract constantly

pros: Everyone there is friendly and the job teaches you great communication skills. Everyone is trained so if you have no experience you aren't at a loss.
cons: Work is based off of surveys we have to complete, and about once a year we have a "survey drought" which means you don't have solid work for between a few weeks to a few months. Unfortunately, this can be due to inept employees.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student
pros: Many friendly teachers and students, excellent classes, interesting research, excellent weather
cons: It does suck to be a poor graduate student, and you sacrifice a lot for your family for an eventual expectation of a brighter future.

review_title: faculty is not as good as it thinks it is
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: palm trees? alligators? bad weather? easy to get accepted into, thank God there is a union
cons: slave wages, non existent mentoring, money spent in all the wrong places, graduate students treated like dogs,

review_title: I have had a great time working here
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: I think that the best parts of working at the university of florida are the many people offering many networking opportunities for those looking for jobs and internships.
cons: The fact that there are so many people can make it easy to be lost in the crowd, so you must be willing to be an independent hard worker if attending this university.

pros: In my particular unit, I have a great boss that wants to support my professional growth, but I can't say that for all units. Cost of living in Gainesville is low. Benefits are wonderful!
cons: Low Pay, Jaded workers, demanding students (but you will have those anywhere you go really)

pros: At University of Florida, you will get real time teaching as well as grading experience by checking by the student's exams and homeworks. You will actually solve the queries brought by students on behalf of your professor.
cons: I really can't think of any cons regarding this position. You just need to get some time out of your busy schedule to spend it with the students.

pros: Great to study and work at the same time. Flexible hours and the work is not hard at all. Close to the library and Midtown so easy access and transportation.
cons: Can be dull at times and work can pick up especially during the beginning times of the semester because of financial aid disbursements during that time

job_title: Tech Support Specialist in Gainesville, FL
pros: I never have trouble getting time off. I get a ton of Vacation and Sick time. I love working for the department I work for.
cons: There aren't too many cons to my were I work. I would say that if you want to work for somewhere that you can get overtime this is not the place for you. Its very much a 9-5 job and no more.

review_title: Work at UFL as a PhD student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Excellent facilities for work. Cost effective education! Decent amount of holidays. Great benefits for students in terms of gym, free bus access etc.
cons: Politics can creep into work environments.  Professors can abuse their authority. Research groups focusing on a common area do not communicate with each other.

job_title: Southwest Rec Gym Trainer in Gainesville, FL
pros: Working on a college campus is amazing because you have access to all of their resources as well as a fun and relaxed environment
cons: The pay was a little low for my liking but the pros of picking my schedule and an easy commute to work far outweighed this minor inconvenience

pros: great work environment, good people to work with, very supportive. The town is a college town and has its own positives and negatives.
cons: not many cons. The traffic is heavy for a small town like gainesville. Its a nice college town.

job_title: Ph D Candiate in Gainesville, FL
pros:
- Great grad student benefits
- Lots of resources to take advantage of
cons:
- Gainesville is not the most exciting town when it's not football season (regardless of fan-dom, football season brings a lot of other activities to the area)
- Advising can be hit or miss

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Good exposure to industry. Lots of inputs from the industry. Most of the projects are partially sponsored by industry
cons: Everything depends on your faculty adviser. If you get a good adviser then it would be really helpful for you. In certain cases. Most professors in UF are one of best in their field though. Taking courses and doing research at the same time may get a little hectic though.

pros: Nice, relaxed environment, nice cultural mix of people. Health insurance for grad students, low living expenses due to small city.
cons: Salary could be better. Each year rent goes up but salary stays the same. Town is not as cheap as you might expect.

pros: Easy job with little requirements. Had to organize room meetings every now and then, but nothing much. Do not do PA! Not worth it, and no pay incentive.
cons: Time consuming. Staff wasn't fully committed to helping out, and it was badly organized.

review_title: There are many volunteering opportunities at UF
pros:
If you don't even have work experience at a McDonalds, being a volunteer at UF can pad your resume while you focus on getting internships/research.
Most of the time the work you do will impact you or other students directly. Very flexible with a student's schedule.
cons: No pay (volunteer position). Sometimes they overestimate the number of volunteers they'll need and you'll end up feeling useless.

review_title: computational methods to solve mechanical engineering problems
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: You will learn a lot and you will contribute to the field. There are very good proffessors working along with you.
cons: Pay is less as a graduate student. There is no team to work with. The advisor is usually very busy

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: 1. diversified research environment and professionals 2. multi-disciplinary educational program 3. good management (especially engineering) 4. vibrant environment 5. free environment
cons: 1. emphasis in sport more than research 2. a college town 3. not easily to find local intern 4. not too many resource for future career

pros: Good learning environment, good feedback from bosses. Friendly people, nice bosses, very flexible and understanding when you need time off
cons: Work can be stagnant sometimes, in between semesters and all. But once school starts you have to work 3times harder to catch up with the volume of students

review_title: Working as an academic physician in the UF Health.
job_title: Clinical Assistant Professor in Gainesville, FL
pros: Large university, lots of opportunities for collaboration. Gainesville is a great small town to live in and raise the family, easy access to big cities and coast.
cons: Despite being a sunshine state, everything that happens in the College of Medicine is opaque. As a physician, trying to do what is good for the patient is challenging. There is old boys network culture here.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student and get paid to teach.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Freedom to teach.  The teaching load is fairly balanced with studies.  There is a lot of autonomy.  They don't giver over your teaching too much.
cons: Compensation could always be more.  In general, funding is down for all departments and the road between administration and departments seems to keep getting wider.

review_title: Opinion from the UF ABE Dept.
pros: My experience from the Agricultural and Biological Engineering (ABE) Dept. has went very well. It has a very pleasant working environment, faculty and staff are friendly, and are willing to help. Co-workers are great and so are the students that attend classes in the Dept. I cannot comment on other Dept.'s.
cons: Have not found any, but if I do I will update my review.

pros: The benefits can't be beat. Love President Fuchs, he genuinely cares for the students. Good job security if you do what you are supposed to.
cons: Some obvious favorism, at least in my department.  Parking is horrendous, expensive to buy a permit and then you are lucky to find a spot, which are usually VERY far away from the office.

review_title: You can make the most out of it, if you want!
pros:
Great opportunity to network
Gainesville is a college town growing into a big city, so a lot of opportunity out there
UF is one of the top 10 public colleges
cons: UF is not Harvard, Stanford or MIT. Opportunities are plentiful and you will have to make the most of it yourself.

review_title: Good people, but institutional inertia and politics blunt effectiveness
pros: Good people many at the top of their fields; many state-of-the-art medical facilities; excellent benefits; flexibility
cons: Academic politics; all of the problems that come with being a state agency (budget, oversight, etc. that change on the whims of people not doing the work);

pros: I work at the UFPA and it has been a wonderful experience.  Very flexible schedule, the staff is down to earth and friendly, and its a pretty cool place to work at.
cons:
Parking. I understand why they have to charge, but also spending over 200 a year to park at your job for a year is ridiculous.

Otherwise, I have no cons for working at UFPA.

review_title: Learned a lot about software development
pros:
I can concentrate on your interests and research
good environment to study and live. 
people in University of Florida are quite nice.
cons: the economy environment is not so competitive. there is not so many information technology companies in the city as in California.

review_title: Large size of University opens up many opportunities
pros: Many resources are available to accomplish your work- from facilities to workforce. Creative and motivated energy of the University is also invigorating.
cons: Because many people around are young, you have to do some extra hand-holding, but you also have a chance to find talent.

review_title: Wonderful people to work with, always looking to improve the student experience.
job_title: Marketing & Design Student Manager in Gainesville, FL
pros: The people are very passionate about what they do, from working with students to providing for the Union as a whole. Everyone is very friendly, the location is great (it's in the middle of campus), and I was happy with the salary.
cons: The bureaucratic system that keeps higher education afloat. Sometimes there was just too much red tape.

pros: Great Job, allows you to choose your own hours. The workplace community is great and the office is centrally located on campus
cons: Honestly, this is a solid gig. Very few disadvantages if any. Sometimes there aren't many available tasks to get done in a shift.

review_title: Grad student at large public university
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Lots of resources for research, access to journals, and databases. Huge wealth of information in the professors and post-docs across many colleges and most are willing to help where they can.
cons: The administration is very slow and bureaucratic. Reimbursements for work-related travel took months which is painful for low wage grad students.

pros: Large university with a plethora of opportunities for continued growth through classes, seminars, cultural events, sporting events.  Communication through the ranks and between departments seems to excellent with a school this size.
cons: You aren't going to get rich working in education.

pros: Nice campus and a great place to live in. Faculty and staff members are mostly very nice people. Lots of smart professionals across different disciplines and great opportunities to learn and build your career.
cons: Depend on the position you're in and projects you work on, sometimes it could be stressful especially when working under certain timeline, but hey, that's what the nice gym is for, right?

review_title:
It
It's Great to be a Florida Gator
pros: They were able to work around my class schedule and I could work for just a couple hours between classes if needed.  It was located on campus and within walking distance to classes.
cons: It can be difficult to manage working while in school, but working for the university helps because they understand that you have to be in classes as well.

job_title: IT Desktop Support Technician in Gainesville, FL
pros: Great place to learn computers, great management and lots of responsibilities. There was plenty of interesting work to tackle and smart people to learn from.  Work life balance was great.
cons: Bureaucracy, red tape. Performance isn't financially rewarded, and there are a lot of under-performant employees that are hard to get rid of.  Compensation isn't great, but work/life balance and benefits probably make up for it.

review_title: PA-C at UF, Department Of Urology
pros: Great place to work.  Super people, good benefits, good working environment.
cons: State cut backs on benefits hurt some, but still better than most.  The Department changed an agreement we had as to hours and days worked.  My fault for not having a contract signed.

review_title: Research assistant at Embedded Systems Lab
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Be a part-time research assistant, I can focus on my PhD at the same time. The advisor meets with me twice a week and he keeps pushing you to work.
cons: It is a lot of pressure working here. You have to learn to think about research ideas, quickly verify them and implement them. These are not cons, I would say they are challenges.

pros: Excellent University have enjoyed my time as a student. Some great professors. Football games are great at the University of Florida.
cons: Fluids and heat department needs some new professors. The only professors that teaches Fluid Dynamics is one of the worst professors I've had

pros:
- flexible adviser 
- plenty of collaborators available
- fellowships to cover tuition, room, and board
- great party school
cons:
- strictly a college town
- university values teachers that publish quantity not quality
- teachers that aren't well funded may not be able to pay for conferences

review_title: Working at the University of Florida as a GRA was great!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros:
I was able to supplement my income during grad school.
Learn some hard skills as I did the research.
I was also able to contribute to a worth-wild project!
cons:
It was tedious at time, however still rewarding.
Jobs in your specific skill set are hard to come by at times.

review_title: I had a great learning experience at UF that opened a lot of doors for my future
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: I had an amazing education filled with opportunity that I may not have had at other schools. In the meantime, I gained valuable career experience, so that upon graduating, I had work experience.
cons: The area is limited; I cannot stay in Gainesville and expect to find a job here!

review_title: Great place, losing funding for arts
pros: Wonderful atmosphere for learning and a great university. There are already a large number of staff who are enjoyable to work with.
cons: Hardship in the arts arena, fights for funding are ongoing. Days when every other light would be off to save electricity!

review_title: Great, but needs to reduce disparities between job classes
pros: UF is great. Depending on which department you work in, things run smoothly and you get a lot of perks.
cons: OPS employees are not treated the same as TEAMS with regards to benefits, how you pay for parking details etc. So if you are looking for a long-term position, make sure it's not OPS.

job_title: Administrative Support Assistant II in Gainesville, FL
pros: The benefits are amazing, as well as the time off. As long as you are not associated with the College of Medicine and considered Clinical you receive great Holiday time around Christmas/New Year.
cons: They charge you an arm and a leg for parking, and there is hardly ever any good spots. Be prepared for small parking spaces and at least a 10 minute walk into your office.

pros: good with scheduling, prestigeous university to work for, pay is not too bad, decent opportunities for upward advancement within your department
cons: management is often poorly trained, workers are generally college aged or students and therefore can make the work environment juvenile and catty

pros: Great benefits, plenty of time off, great way to meet a very diverse group of people
cons: Lack of raises, never knowing who's head will be on the chopping block next despite one's seniority. Can't move up without a degree.

review_title: Wasn't ideal. Treated like a lowly personal assistant.
pros: Free food in the kitchen, great coworkers, being close to classes, good pay
cons: Unrealistic amount of work for a part-time position, boss treated position like her personal assistant, negative office politics, unhealthy work environment

pros: Education, exposure, great classes,infrastructure, projects, good visibility when it comes to attending conferences, presentations or plant visits. reputed university
cons: very big school, too many students, many students dont get a project to work on until their final year. small town

pros: it is a beautiful city, close to beach and have many lakes,  not high living cost , good education for children.
cons: it is not a big city, basiclly it is a village  for university, not a lot entertainning, it is kind of boring, expecially for kids. no big shopping mall, you have to drive 2 hours to find a big mall.

pros: There are many employment opportunities at UF and the institution provides great benefits.  It also provides employee education assistance and great leave benefits.  A very diverse student population and workplace.
cons: The shear size of the institution some times slows thing down, but that is the same with any large organizations or institutions.

job_title: Network Administration Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: I was tasked with researching and working on new network security solutions because full time employees were too busy.  The work was mostly up to date and relevant.  I learned a lot and everyone was very friendly and approachable.
cons: It's clear they are short staffed and would benefit from employing more people to help advance projects more quickly.

review_title: Bad benefits for TAs, even though they teach the majority of classes
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: It's a good school in a relatively fun town.
cons: Terrible insurance benefits, student fees have gone up 80% in the past 5 years--and TAs have to pay student fees, even though they are the ones teaching most of the classes.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Belle Glade, FL
pros: Highly competitive compared to all the land grant universities in the United States of America. Great interdisciplinary programs and laboratory facilities.
cons: Big on sports and that can sometimes affect the capability of students to do research. Too many social distractions on campus.

pros: Great and friendly staff. The weather is usually very nice. Bike friendly community. Nice location. Tuition waiver for grad students on assistantship.
cons: Sometimes funding can be pulled or lost. Gainesville is probably the farthest city from the coast in FL.  Gradschool takes up all your free time and youll wish you had more time to enjoy  FL.

review_title: Great place to learn highly sought after skills
job_title: Market Research Graduate Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Learned skills necessary to obtain a great job after school.  Spent many hours programming in SAS.  There is no class that can provide these skills the same way working for two years as a market research graduate assistant could.
cons: Not all goals/tasks were clearly defined, but this is not uncommon in graduate school.

pros: Pays well compared to other college job options. Super flexible hours generally. The projects can be good ways to get introduced to fields of work you are interested. Get to work on interesting projects!
cons: Work can be very theoretical depending on the lab you're in. A lot of the labs do not have windows either which can make things kind of sad.

pros: Lots of flexibility, great learning environment, huge research community with many opportunities for interdisciplinary research, and wonderful colleagues
cons: Low salary (typically charge student fees, which is unfair because it requires graduate students to pay to work at the university) and organization leaders often resist change

pros: As soon as I started the job I was trained efficiently and the outgoing administrative assistant took her time to help me learn the job to allow everything to run smoothly in her absence. I loved working here.
cons: There could have been more structure to my daily duties, but I prioritized as things came to me.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Gainesville, FL
pros: UF ranks higher, but not the College of Medicine. Still the best college town in Florida.
cons: Too many politics in UF. Less industry opportunity around. Because the expanding of UF, Gainesville is growing faster, cost of housing/renting was increased, and the neighborhood is not safe as before.

job_title: Undergraduate Student in University Of, FL
pros: Surrounded by great peers and supervisors who genuinely care about your well-being. You get to work with people and you have the opportunity to network and grow. They understand that student staff are students first and will work with you.
cons: Demanding, somewhat difficult to balance with full time education, they are very strict and unyielding. Can be cryptic about pay

review_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant. Great opportunity to learn with an intense work load
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Great atmosphere. professors are friendly and want you to succeed and learn. Responsibilities make grow and develop technical as well as interpersonal skills.
cons: Work load can be above more than the 10hr per week established for graduate teaching assistants. This can interfere and negatively impact your own classwork and/or research.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Able to create my own hours while working on important and personally fulfilling research under the supervision of a respected professor.
cons: Make sure you and your professor agree upon your hours and responsibilities in advance of accepting the position. At times, it was difficult to know what was expected of the position/how to move forward (research is tricky like that).

pros: Always on the leading edge of software to work with. Current gen equipment with which to work. Professional development opportunities abound
cons: Communication can be lacking at times, leaders can be disconnected from staff. Parking is a pain when students are in session

review_title: Great opportunity - pays for a graduate degree and great work experience!
pros: Working as a grad assistant is the best way to earn a graduate degree. For 20 hours a week all tuition is paid and you can gain priceless experience.
cons: Sometimes it can be challenging to balance school and work priorities, this can depend on how flexible your supervisor is.

pros:
Able to easily adjust hours around school/personal schedule.
Work is usually quite easy.
Able to study during downtime.
Most coworkers are great to interact with.
cons:
Pay isn't great.
Need to be adaptable and able to troubleshoot problems you've never dealt with before.
Plenty of arbitrary rules that don't improve our service.
Can't work more than 30 hours a week as a student employee.

review_title: The experience with UF is rewarding.
pros: The professors of UF are knowledgeable and helpful.  The live here in Gainesville is comfortable at an economically affordable cost.
cons: You might feel a bit too hot and humid in summer.  But finally the AC just helps.

job_title: Computer Information Scince in Gainesville, FL
pros: The university of Florida is the largest employer in Gainesville, Florida.  The benefits of working for the university are great.
cons: Hiring process takes a long time.  Be prepared to wait up to a year to get hired.

pros: Gainesville is a nice place to live. Central Florida has a balmy climate, low crime, lots of water for boating, fishing, or bird-watching.
cons: Like other public universities, UF has good departments and bad departments. I worked in one of the bad departments, with the most arrogant, least capable staff I ever encountered.

review_title: Good chance to train yourself as an independent teacher
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: The salary that i receive is enough to support all my living expense, can improve my teaching experience as an independent instructor
cons: This amount of salary  Can afford Only myself when you live on campus and do nothing else but research. But i heard that new tas receive more than this

pros: Healthcare options, ability to advance, if stay for a minimum amount of time, the state pension on retirement is amazing
cons: Sometimes you may have to play politics depending on the department, parking even for employees is expensive and should be free since not all departments make very much in an hourly wage

pros: Work is not hard.  Given a large degree of freedom to work at your own pace.  Friendly environment and convenient location on campus.
cons: Pay is dismal (minimum wage).  Management is often inefficient and frustrating.  Early mornings (7am).  Many confusing rules that seem to have no purpose or bearing on the job.

review_title: Great depending on your mentor, Administration is completely incompetent
pros:
Similar to most research universities
The weather
Accessible campus
Lab spaces are nice
Freedom to do research
Great access to publications
cons:
Intellectual culture lacking
Few top tier researchers
Administration is wholly incompetent
Most administrative functions are completed ON PAPER
Lack of technological support
HORRIBLE core facilities

review_title: It was nice working and earning as a student to support day-to-day expenses.
pros: They offered a time Flexible schedule to work between the classes. The management and staff were helpful and supportive.
cons: The amount of work was too much to handle for the limited resources we had. Also, the compensation they offered was comparatively less.

job_title: Computer Support Analyst in Gainesville, FL
pros: Benefits and retirement are worth the red tape.
cons: Left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing in the larger departments.

review_title: This job has been great at working well into my busy life as a student.
pros: The hours and flexibility are that of no other job. Given how it is a student job, there is a lot of understanding in scheduling.
cons: No cons, other than the fact that growth is limited. However, it is only a student job not a career.

review_title: Great place to gain experience if you can snag a position
job_title: OPS Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Wonderful place to get experience in your field of study.
cons:
Research assistant and OPS positions are very competitive due to the number of students and individuals applying to positions.
OPS employees are at the whim of campus-wide openings/closures which can be problematic if the university is your sole source of income.

pros: I had a great experience.  Lots of professional development, opportunities for advancement, and I felt like I worked in a respectful and professional environment.  Having a good supervisor goes a long way, but I think UF is a great place to work.
cons: It's a big place and the wheels of change turn slowly.

review_title: Good working environment to work in!
pros:
Always hours available 
Employees are a family & always enjoy in work events
They stand for the patients
cons:
No health benefits 
No paid time off 
Expect you to work with minimal breaks 
Monitor everything you do

review_title: Choose your work schedule, but sometimes hard to meet hours because shifts are during school hours
job_title: Stephen C O'Connell Center Crew Member in Gainesville, FL
pros: flexible schedule, fun events, great supervisors, short shifts
cons: although flexible schedule, events were set in advanced and you are required to work a minimum of 25 hours per month. sometimes difficult if your schedule doesn't allow you to work the events scheduled for that month.

pros:
Advisors and supervisors are really helpful and supportive.
Students work hard which makes it a pleasure to teach.
People in general are very friendly and helpful around UF.
cons:
There seems to be some favoritism with certain people.
Pay is not enough to pay bills each month, but tuition is free.

review_title: It's a good place to start the career, the school is big and beautiful. The people are nice.
pros:
The people are nice to you, and the place is beautiful. 
The facilities are new and good.
The weather is good.
cons:
The efficiency is low in the university.
The using fee for equipment are expensive.
Cannot keep good young stuff stay.

pros: Decent hours and flexibility. Really good for people who are going to school at the same time. also, everyone is mostly friendly.
cons: There is not much of an opportunity for upward mobility. Positions are mostly set in stone. This is usually the case in universities as large as the University of Florida.

pros: Great administration, nice teachers, lovely office in a renovated space, flexible and helpful coworkers, generally an exceptionally positive work environment.
cons: UF tends to have a low pay for admin support and secretarial staff and many positions are OPS (part time/temporary) without benefits. Gainesville in general has lower pay for skilled positions compared to other Florida cities.

job_title: Technology Consultant in University Of, FL
pros: Its quick to get a job as a student at the University of Florida. They have a dedicated website that you can go to in order to get a job.
cons: You max out at 20 hours per week unless you get an extended permit from your academic adviser. Besides that the hours are pretty great!

pros: Great place to jump off your career. Always offered opportunities to expand your skill set.
cons: Limited opportunities for advancement. Low glass ceiling. Unless you're in the right place at the right time doing the right things.

pros: This is a nice public university. It is comprehensive, so it is easy to meet people from various disciplines. Human resource takes care of pretty much everything for employees. And the most important, things are improving all the time.
cons: Since this is a public university, you can imagine that the pay level is lower than some private universities.

job_title: Technical Support Consultant & Trainer in Gainesville, FL
pros: Great benefits. Plenty of vacation days. Beautiful campus. Diversity all around. If you get in a good position in a good department, you can lock in for a lifetime.
cons: The position you are in can get stagnant. Lots of hires from within so good for current employees, but makse it difficulty for the outside to get in.

pros: Great benefits: EVERYTHING life, dental, medical, vision, and your choice HMO or PPO FSA, lots of days off.
cons: Bureaucracy! State decides salary increases not your work ethic. Staff are lazy/don't care attitude - hard to get work done.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Compared to other top-rated universities, UF employers have a sense of work/life balance. I truly believe it has to do with the weather. Don't get me wrong, you have to work a lot, but I feel the work I put it is more rewarding.
cons: Graduate student fees should not be forced upon.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Awesome environment, got to learn a lot and developed my communication skills and interpersonal skills actually learnt the difference between taught and lab courses and their importance.
cons: Cant say i had many problems here, a very healthy environment and if given a little more freedom and independence it would have been better.

review_title: Great environment that helps students pay for college
pros: I worked as a Student Assistant for most of my time while attending undergraduate at UF. My supervisors were very approachable and gave students a good deal of flexibility with studies and work.
cons: The work could be tedious some days and brings a very limited impact to one's resume.

review_title: My experience working here has been great.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator III in Gainesville, FL
pros: Strong research programs,  many opportunities, good benefits, good people. Leading academic medical center that treats patients from all over the state and region.
cons: Direct promotion opportunities may be limited in each department,  so you may have to look to other departments for career advancement. Must pay for parking.

pros:
Flexible schedule - I am able to work as many hours as I want and my supervisors understand that school is my number one priority.
I get a raise every two semesters
cons: I started at minimum wage and even though I get a raise every two semesters the amount is only a few cents.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Good working experience and nice faculty members and colleges. Have good restaurants nearby campus. But overall a good place to work for students
cons: Overall a good place to work for . Pay rate is not very high and management can be improved, micromanagement of students for some faculty members

pros:
The academic atmosphere does not stifle the practical contributions of the university. 
UF understands the magnitude of its presence in the state, as well as the region, and uses its weight to reach out into the rural areas of the state and push for progress.
cons: Gainesville is up an up-and-coming city. Still coming.

pros: Since most of time, I work with professors and other Ph.D.students, I can feel everyone around me are passionate about what they do, and that's very inspiring.
cons: Same here, since everyone is very passionate about what they do, so overwork without extra payment is very common. However, I think it also depends on the lab/center.

review_title: I enjoyed my work environment and co-workers
pros: It's a very positive work environment with predominantly happy workers and with good potential for growth in the administrative side.
cons: As a state education environment, there's a fair bit of complacency among some of the staff, and there's not a great way to ensure performance of a consistently high quality.

pros: It is a very beautiful college town, it has multiple great recreation facilities, and very helpful people in the administration.
cons: There is not any major downside for University of Florida. The only thing could be the smallness of the town but still it has many good aspects of the big cities.

review_title: I had a great experience working as a Student Assistant
pros: Flexible with hours since I still had to go to classes, and I was involved multiple student organizations. My supervisors were cool, friendly, and very knowledgeable.  An easy job, and the pay wasn't amazing, but it paid the bills.
cons: Most jobs required federal work study.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Excellent benefits and compensation.
cons: Some research assistants have unrealistic demands placed on them, not leaving enough time for classes and personal research (experience can vary widely depending on who you assist).

review_title: Prestigeous program, many centers and opportunities
pros: There are many research centers and many opportunities to pursue academic career. Pay is relatively higher that other institutes in the state given low costs of Gainesville.
cons: This job can be unstable . No or little promotion. Everyone is treated the same way so hardworker does not get more acknowledgement.

pros: The people I worked with were really great and had been in the department for years. Everyone seemed to get along fine and care about their fellow co-workers.
cons: Parking is horrible on UF campus. Students are not allowed to work more than 20 hours a week for OPS jobs.

pros: I enjoyed working here for 3yrs... Good pay, great benefits, especially when i got really sick, i was able to still keep my job and management was willing to work with me in my unit.
cons: Not much negative i can say.

job_title: Administrative Support Assistant II in Gainesville, FL
pros:
Health Benefits, Time-off, Schedule, Flexibility, Location. 
The University has a great benefit package. Great opportunities to continue education. Flexibility with schedule is great!
cons: Upward Mobility - It was very difficult to find a position to move up to that was equally enjoyable with the same or better pay. Parking is atrocious.

review_title: Geared more towards administrative career development than any other type - a problem at a research heavy institution.
job_title: Senior Biological Scientist in Gainesville, FL
pros: Nice spot in Florida to be; decent compensation; positive academic research environment lacks the negative intensity of other US areas.
cons: Politics-heavy; constant restructuring/ re-branding give appearance of lack of focus; minimal positive intensity of other US research areas.

job_title: Dialysis Acute RN in Jacksonville, FL
pros: always enough hours whether you are full time or part time, benefits for part time employees
cons: specifically the dialysis unit is run by very gossipy nurses, back stabbing is very common, management does not intervene, the patients can behave however they want

pros: Not much work , You can study during the job , Friendly Work Environment, Work on weekends.
cons: Nothing as such other than some hectic days where there will be lot of problems on a single day.

job_title: Supervisor of Evaluations and Promotions in Saint Augustine, FL
pros: Supportive and enthusiastic management teams, interesting and engaging work that actually works to help the respondents who complete surveys, independent and self-guided shifts
cons: Dialing for more than one shift a day can become tedious and monotonous

job_title: Business Services Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros:
-Great environment 
-Great Team 
-Awesome Managers/ supervisors
-Opportunity to develop in special projects
-Diversity
cons:
-Difficult schedule changes 
-Long hours without rest during summer hours

review_title: UF is a prety good place to work
pros: Good place to work. It is very laid back, unless your PI is an assistant or associate professor...in which case you will be pushed to work very hard.
cons: Their admin people move pretty slow .

review_title: Great place to work and enjoy the life
pros: UF is a place that has great diversity and also people are very nice. The collaborative activity is very active between different departments.
cons: The university spent a lot on athletic aspect. Hence, if you are not a sports fan, you might not be happy as well.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros:
Large support base at university.
Small, cheap city is very accommodating to grad student stipend.
Great access to hospital for collaborations on medical research projects.
cons: Being far from large cities makes industry partners hard to find. Lots of undergrads can get annoying if you're looking for a more 'adult' lifestyle.

pros: I love how understanding they are about student schedules and it is a great work atmosphere.
cons: Sometimes the lower-level people have suggestions that would work well, but the aren't always listened to.

pros: The hours are flexible. The management is always friendly and encouraging. They understand that you are a student so your studies come first.
cons: When working positions that revolve around sports such as football, your shifts can get cancelled if the team decides to cancel practice.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Good support from my advisor, large variety of different research opportunities, nice college town with easy transportation system and easily accessible by bicycle.
cons: Things are a little dated compared to my other university, and the cost of living is a bit higher. As a GRA I spend $550 on my shared apartment.

job_title: OPS Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros:
Most of these pros are specific to my lab and boss

-Flexible hours
-Relaxed, friendly work environment 
-Great resume booster especially for students 
-Performing biological research is intellectually stimulating
-Good mix of sitting/standing/activity
cons:
-Pay could be better
-No benefits due to hourly OPS position
-No ability to move upward without getting a master's or PhD degree.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: If you are a student, the University offers many undergraduate research positions to gain experience in your field. Flexible hours. Good pay. Never work when school is out.
cons: - It all depends on which researcher or department you work for. I have not found any cons so far

review_title: Long hours with very little pay
pros:
- Good starter job
- It's most people's first job so they're not too harsh on mistakes
- Get to work with all students
- Flexible work hours
cons:
- Long hours
- There's a ton of people who work in the bookstore so it doesn't feel very personal
- Favoritism 
- Extremely low pay

pros:
-On-campus job was easy to access as a full-time student
-Direct deposit paychecks
-Well-organized program, hiring process, training

pros: The weather is nice. The gyms are nice. Football tickets are subsidized. The campus is large. The football team should do well next year.
